RATING: 9
What an awesome design. I love how the auctions generate random piles of stuff that players will value differently. I love how you have to factor in not just spending your bid tiles for the round, but more than likely giving them to someone else. I love that you can call the auction when it suits you to force other players' hands. And I love push-your-luck mechanics!

First time I've given the fabled "let's play again!" in as long as I can remember. Fast becoming a (very late to the party) Knizia fan. 

And having played the game, the FFG version looks to make the different tile functions really hard to internalise for new players. Plus I love the wooden sun tiles in the 'classic' version - leaning towards that one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[COLOR=#FFFFFF][BGCOLOR=#CC3300][b]PRINT'N'PLAY version[/b][/BGCOLOR][/COLOR]
[I]tl;dr - Ra is an immensely entertaining auction game by Reiner Knizia -- the game is so good I want the published version![/I]
[COLOR=#CCCCFF]____________________________[/COLOR]

Ra is a simply complex auction game from Reiner Knizia that's very enjoyable. On your turn, you draw tiles from the bag one by one, gradually adding to the lot of tiles that are available for auction. Each turn, the player will decide if they want to draw another tile, or bid on the lot and claim it for their tableau. The catch? Each player has only three tokens to bid with -- and they may not be the value he'd like to spend on the lot. 

As such, Ra is a game of evaluating the bids everyone else has remaining, deciding when to pick up a lot with a bid, and making sure to avoid the end of the era with the Ra tiles. Ra tiles make the game even harder, forcing an auction on that turn -- when the board fills up with Ra tiles, the first age is over. After two more ages, the game ends. 

There are many ways to score points: from civilizations, to monuments, to Nile-side farms, to powerful God tiles. All in all, the meat of this game comes down to evaluating the current lot, deciding when to bid, and deciding when to push your luck. This is a brilliant game that has the potential to push 10 with me.

Rather than spend $60 for the new Windrider edition, I spent thrice that in time to craft my own sci-fi themed cardgame version of Ra, and it actually works quite well! We use poker chips for the money and everything fits together nicely. The sci-fi theme is just about as pasted on as the Egypt theme, but I thought it might appeal to more players in my group.

RATING: 8
7 plays / 3,4,5 players

LIKE: Great auction mechanism for swiping the middle value tile. Fun to press-your-luck, hoping for better tiles to try to auction for.
DISLIKE: A difficult game to grasp the first time through. Scoring can be fiddly. Dry. The graphics could use an update.

OVERALL: An impressive game and doesn't take very long to play.

RATING: 7.5
Classic game that I'm proud to own. This is essentially an optimization game and even boarder-line mathy. As such, I'm surprised that I like it as much as I do.  I think it's the push your luck aspect that brings it out of the dull-drums. It's surprisingly deeper and more akin to poker in bluffing than anything else.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ra is a bidding and set collection game with a closed economy. Closed economy in this case means that the game should balance itself through the bidding action. Of course, this implicitly means that there is a learning curve to the game because you cannot estimate the true value of the tiles offer on your first play. I liked the fact that in addition to bidding for tiles, closed economy means that you also bid for your position on the next round. So your choices have an impact on both short and long term.

The only thing that felt a bit weird and was a kind of anticlimax to the game, was the round ends. If there was only one player left in the game with more than one RA-tile short of triggering the round end, he was almost certain to get a full display of goodies without anyone being able to do anything about it. But I reckon this a thing to keep in mind and it is the other players' own fault if they let one player do whatever he likes.

Ra is a classic example of a modern game design without anything but the absolute necessary parts. The result is a game that, maybe is not that flashy and exciting at the first glance when compared with newer games, but offers an experience of reasonable length with a lot meaningful and tough decisions. I do admit that Ra might feel a bit dry at first but if you like bidding games, Ra definitely is one of the better ones. It also was a wonder how good the game feels with just 3 players, which is a rare treat in auction games. Thus Ra deserves a rather high rating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My second favourite of Knizia's auction games (after Modern Art).  I especially like the mechanism that makes your bid have to take into account both the value of the past bid block (which is part of the auction parcel) and the value of giving the block you're bidding with to someone else (in the next auction parcel).  That opens up a world of lowball bid strategies (as does the way people can speed or slow the bidding cycle to suit their tiles).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[i]2017/05/15 - 1 play 3 players[/i]
Early days, but so far my favorite pure auction game. It's quite tense and exciting, and fixed bids make it easy to jump into the game even if you are inexperienced, whereas auction games are often intimidating for newcomers.

The game has lots of tactical elements (because you win bidding tokens you will be able to use next round, the buildup of auction sets, etc), but still allows for a strategy buildup (set collection through the three ages)

Still, I got crushed.

The games has a super fast setup, plays in less than one hour, has zero downtime. Great game for a weekday.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Ra is a subtle and demanding game. It is also a game that I want to like more, but (a) it "suffers" from "location impotence" -- if you sit between players who like to force auctions, you are going to have real trouble getting a good tile selection, and (b) it is an auction game, and I like auctions as a mechanism, not as [b]the[/b] mechanism of the game...

If you like auction games, you need to play Ra. If you don't like auction games you are not going to like Ra, regardless of its devious auction system.

RATING: 7.9
I love Reiner Knizia, and I love this auction game of his.  It is so unique and so interesting and fits together so nicely.  In Knizia form, this game has the simplest of decisions being so hard to make.  Every choice is interesting, and you really feel that you are playing well or not based on the choices.  There is a push your luck element with big gains for succeeding and big loses for pushing too far. Seriously, I love this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ra is a pure auction game and yet it asks its players plenty of difficult questions.  Which of three types of tile that accumulate throughout the game will be my focus?  How concerned am I about point losses for fewest Pharaohs and no civs?  Do I really want to exchange my 16 point bid for a one point bid next epoch?  What is this set worth to me, him and her? Should I add to it or call Ra? Above all, how long til the end of the epoch (I lied, this is also a push your luck game)?

While my play has become somewhat formulaic, I always find some fun in this game. Ra has become a popular standby in my gaming circles. 

My Alea edition is well produced and pleasing to the eye.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Clever but frustrating auction game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ra is a fairly quick set collection auction game that I think is (game designer) Reiner Knizia's loose take on poker.

Gameplay decisions are tied to probabilistic risk assessment and Ra sure does make that into some hedge your bets vs. go-for-broke fun.  Consequently skill at Ra is best judged over multiple plays of the game, not winning any particular instance.

Plays well with 3, 4, or 5.  Takes 30+ mins.
---------------------------------------------------
First play was a big hit!  Myself and three game-friendly-not-really-gamer friends had a lot of fun in a 'trial run' to figure out the rules.  It took me about 20-30 minutes to read through the rules and get an idea of what was going on.  Once that was finished we threw ourselves into the game and after a little bit the brilliance of the game started to show up.  We are looking forward to playing more soon!

RATING: 5
Mathematically sound. Thematically unsound. :P

Also it has serious problems or rather it demands a standard playgroup to really shine. Specifically if there is a new player in the group, the game will be unbalanced because it is not possible for a single player to counter one other player's efforts by himself alone. 
This precondition demands strict playgroup parameters for the game to be good. I consider this a VERY BAD trait in a game hence the low rating.

RATING: 6
[2009] Mayo - 7.5

[2010] El juego consta de 3 días. Cada día, los jugadores pueden comprar hasta 3 lotes de tiles. El día acaba cuando todos los jugadores han comprado sus 3 lotes o cuando los espacios para Ra han sido llenados. Los tiles dan puntos inmediatos o al final del juego, o incluso sirven para evitar perder puntos. Algunos tiles se conservan a lo largo del juego, mientras que otros se pierden al final de cada día. Quien tenga más puntos al final del tercer día será el ganador.

[2014] 6.0
No sé si es porque ya conocemos más juegos, pero salvo por AA solía gustarnos Ra. Jugamos anoche y todos quedamos con la sensación de que no nos gustó...
Ra Dados es muuuuucho mejor, y más rápido.

RATING: 6
Like most of Knizia's games, Ra is mechanically sound. I can see how at one time the clever design of this game impressed game fans. The problem is clever mechanics the only important aspects of a game. They need to also be fun and interesting. The first few times you play it, you feel the former up until you realize it doesn't have much of the latter. A good but not great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My favorite auction game and among my favorite three player games.  It moves quickly but it's constantly posing tough decisions to each player.

There's a wide assortment of tiles that group up and score in different ways.  Some score immediately, some score later, some only score for one player but not another, and some will even hurt some players but not others.  Figuring out what each stash is worth to you (and to a lesser extend, everyone else) is rarely obvious.

Instead of bidding whatever you want, you have to use one of a finite group of fixed value tokens.  There's a lot to consider which token is worth the pot.

And finally, there's a push your luck element in that the round can end before everyone has taken something with each of their tokens.  This pushes players both ways.  Get out early to avoid not cashing in your tokens.  But if you stay in to the end you might be able to clean up with no competition.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

I'm not saying I regret buying this top game as it is so much fun, its just the price tag and kind of one mechanic (albeit a great mechanic) over and over again that makes it feel very light.

EDIT: The one mechanic/choice every turn soon became tiresome and so traded away

RATING: 8.7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 2nd Place 1999[/SIZE][/COLOR]

[i]Posted: 7/27/09, Rated: 9[/i]

"Life is like a sewer: What you get out of it, depends upon what you put into it." - Tom Lehrer

That's about as metaphysical of a statement as I can think of to try to describe [i]Ra[/i].  It is a classic Knizia design: very solid auction mechanics, an intricate scoring schedule, and an Egyptian theme.

I'm not the kind of player to complain about themes being "pasted on," by the way.  A game that is overly thematic tends to have fiddly rules in order to support that theme.  A game with simple, elegant rules is often accused of having its theme "pasted on."  Hogwash.  I prefer games with streamlined rules which can be evaluated objectively.  Theme is a subjective element: the richness of the game world can either increase or diminish the overall experience.  [i]Ra[/i] has a set of well-defined rules which are easy to understand.  The artwork and production value of my copy -- in other words, the execution of the Egyptian "theme" -- greatly enhances my enjoyment of this game.

The foundation of this game is "pushing your luck."  You can try to get more tiles, or you can try to purchase the ones that are already displayed.  You can go too far, though, and end up with nothing.  Such brinksmanship is a solid start to any game.

The challenge of an auction mechanism is found in learning how to value the items up for bid.  In fact, I contend that the longer it takes to acquire this skill, the more enjoyment can be squeezed from a game like [i]Ra[/i].  Once that learning curve has been surmounted, an auction game becomes more deterministic.  And it is here that [i]Ra's[/i] convoluted scoring schedule is both a benefit and a curse: it can take a long time to learn how to value all of the different types of tiles.  Five games would be just a start.  With my family, it's hard to get a game of this weight to the table that many times if they're not "getting it."  By the same token, it is this complexity which gives [i]Ra[/i] longer gaming legs.  It's a paradox.

What does help is the fixed bid mechanism: you can only bid one of your "sun tiles," and there is only one round of bidding.  [i]Ra[/i] pulls this off with far more aplomb than the [i][geekurl=/wiki/page/Spiel_des_Jahres]Spiel des Jahres[/geekurl][/i]-winning [i][thing=110]Auf Achse[/thing][/i].  Their fixed amounts also relax the need to precisely calculate the value of an auction lot.  The interplay between value and purchasing power, flowing on a river of chance is where the beauty of [i]Ra[/i] truly resides.

If I had to pare my collection down to a small number of titles, then [i]Ra[/i] would definitely make the cut.  As it stands today, it's a beautifully-produced game with strong mechanics that doesn't drive enough demand.  We haven't been willing to invest the necessary time to get our full measure of enjoyment from it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

RATING: N/A
R&D
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An excellent (atypical) auction game, and simply excellent game overall. The theme is utterly irrelevant except to provide some visual/conceptual reminders of each tile's function and to make the game visually appealing, but I don't mind that Ra is abstract in this way. (Of course auctioning paintings or houses makes more sense, but if Ra is the better game, does it really matter?) Ra's bidding mechanic (the winner of an auction gains a bidding marker as a part of the current lot, and contributes his to the next) is very clever, and the push-your-luck aspect of drawing tiles (especially when only one player can bid) is good fun. The scoring mechanics are manageable and (critically) result in most lots being at least reasonably valuable to all players (especially when there is time to shift scoring strategies), which is crucial in a game with this much chance. Some may consider the randomness of the draw a downside, but I view it as simply another thing a player must attempt to value: one must attach a value to not only the tiles currently in the lot, but also the tiles that [i]may[/i] be added if no one bids (which may be good or bad!), the likelihood that the desired tiles will be drawn, and the likelihood of being able to use all bidding markers before the round ends. Of course, no one can evaluate this type of uncertainty perfectly and everyone gets burned now and then, but for a game of this weight I don't mind it at all. Ra packs a lot of decisions and competition into a very accessible and playable game. Truly wonderful.(2012-03; revised 2014-02)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5

Second play and I have warmed to this considerably, it seems there is a transition of learning the strategies that needs to be overcome before the real depth of the game is appreciated. Certainly a chunk of luck but managable luck.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For a while I thought I would be sent off to the afterlife with my own unopened copy of Ra for the journey, but after 5 years on our shelf we finally broke its seal!

p: People keep telling me this is an auction game. I guess it is, and the flood of auctions is certainly a hint. Yet somehow it didn't feel like one at all. It has recently dawned on me which auction games I do like: it's the ones that allow me to play poker with other people's impulse to play chicken. And trying to find the offer that is to poor to take but to costly to let go is what this game is all about. Mentioning auction games to me triggers many scarred memories of playing rich-getting-richer games until whatever arbitrary victory condition was met, usually involving me losing all my money. This is the other sort, the Knizia one.

Values of tiles are relative as they are different for each player. Each player can win an equal amount of auctions and only has set values to bid with, triggering an intriguing dance of high and low bidding tiles. Winning tiles with a low bid can be far more important than securing a high value set with the highest one, and forcing the play of a high value bid on a mediocre set of tiles  is where judgment calls and skill will shine through. Triggering auctions with low values to pose dilemmas for those holding the powerful bid tiles is crucial, and your success at using  this mechanism will make or break the game for you. Hey, even the game mechanism itself poses its own dilemmas, as hanging on for a better set can be risky as the game round can end abruptly, but strangely tempting too as the rewards can be huge.

I understand some people dislike the "luck of the draw" element, but to me that is arguing against the one element that is crucial to the make-up and enjoyment of this game. It's like saying Bridge would be so much better if only people had more control over the cards they were dealt at the start. Dealing with what is presented in front of you is ALL the challenge here, and Knizia has come up with a rather nice series of additional balances that guarantees that no single move can be a winning move, and that most moves also benefit other players in those dark and mysterious trickling down ways of his.

Whether you like this or not will for a large part depend on how intuitive maths comes to you. There are a lot of gamers around here who will rank this as a "light" game, but I can see several people in my immediate surroundings who are frequent, well-versed and enthusiastic gamers, who will find weighing up the relative and interlinked values of the tiles to themselves and other players quite hard work, and slightly off-putting, especially against players who can spot mathematical formulas in their breakfast cereal. On the whole, if you don't run away screaming when you have to figure out the relative value of each situation, this will make for some of the best dilemma gaming you can think of. However, I am not alway in the mood to play a game where contsant concentration is a requirement, and this one certainly is one of those. We also have the sort of group in which this is played slightly slower than it could be.

I haven't made my mind up if I prefer this over "Medici" or not, and for instance "Geschenkt" seems to pose a similar level of challange, judgement and risk-taking in a much simpler game. I do like this a lot, but how much will only become clear with further plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This game is a gas with 4+ players.

RATING: 9
After playing two real-life games and several against AI, I feel pretty confident saying that this game is brilliant. It takes the inherently fun and suspenseful press-your-luck formula and adds healthy tactical depth by both presenting it using constant turn rotation (whodathunk THAT was possible?) and combining it with an elegant pseudo-auction mechanic. This is the sort of simple but deep game that very few people in the world would be able to create, but Knizia is one of them.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I think I figured it out.  
1.) Who doesn't like out-gaming and scoring stuff at auctions?  It's like ebay - the game.

2.) But the thing is, even if you win your auctions, and you do a good job...the larger picture in mind is what really matters, and it's hard to accurately get that big picture to mean something per the randomness of the tiles.  Because every auction that comes up is ultimately worth something, so why not try to win everything?

It comes down to, I like luck, but at a certain point you might as roll a dice, and whatever player number comes up, declare him or her the winner, and Ra is dangerously close to that with quite a few direct luck-to-win moments.

...all this said, I do like to play this game, and that's ultimately what matters.  

Knizia tends to either have too much luck and little think-ahead for my taste, or he creates an experience where winning because of luck and strategy creates a feeling of euphoria and smugness unparalleled except by winning a large sum of money at a roulette wheel.  This is his finest work that I've played.

04-03-14
Lowered to a '7', maybe even a 6.  I played this a bunch on the ipad, and I'm absolutely sick of it. Every other game...  I play smart, and sure enough, someone plays risky and essentially wins the game by drawing 47 tiles before being the only bidder and getting it.

Don't get me wrong, I love luck...  but it seems like the rule rather than the exception and when it does swing in one direction, it destroys the game.   

I love other games where I perpetually roll '1' or something, and that doesn't bother me because usually that is some incredibly bad luck...you just have to enjoy it for what it is.  With this, I feel like there's a 50/50 shot at it just being a pure-luck experience.

Sold:  The feel of this game HAS to exist in an easier to teach package with less game-breaking frustration.  SWAT works, but I'm thinking even better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Okay so Ra is an auction game, yes. But in my mind the real game under that pretty, ancient Egyptian wrapping (no, not the mummified kind) is about knowing [i]when[/i] to call an auction more than what happens once the bidding actually starts. It's about timing, about forcing your opponents to bid on slightly worse lots than they'd like, about pushing your luck to get a big payoff before Ra closes out the round. I love it. It's quick, it's that special mix of rules-light but gameplay-deep, and you get to exclaim to the table, "I INVOKE RA!" in your most dramatic voice. I could see this one going up to a 9 with more plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
A well-executed auctioning game. Good production with vibrant tiles and one of the best auction concepts I've seen to date. The "negative" tiles force players to make tough decisions on some auction blocks. The scoring methods are diverse with points being awarded for the winners in certain categories (and occasionally subtracted for other categories) as well certain sets of tiles. Players can only win a maximum of 9 auction blocks, which makes for an exciting game of chicken as the game ends when everyone has used up their final auction token or when the Ra tiles (used to drive the pace of the game and encourage bidding) have reached a certain limit.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
In Ra, you are pushing your luck to see what tiles come out which you will be bidding on using a closed system of sun tiles with numbers 1-16. On your turn you can either draw a tile to add to the row, or "invoke ra" and start a round of bidding. The tiles have some set collection, with permanent and temporary tiles, and among those are ra tiles which automatically start a round of bidding, and will end the round once you have enough of them.

I honestly didn't think much of this game during my first play, but shortly afterward the cleverness of the bidding system started to dawn on me. While pretty simple to learn (probably next step past gateway), there are always interesting choices here. It seems to move at a good clip, doesn't seem very prone to AP, and while an early lead is certainly positive, you are never really out of the game, as a daring push in the last round could net you a lot of points. just watch out for that last ra tile...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Can be fun. A bit deeper than most auction games, but pretty dry, like all of theis designer's games.

RATING: 8

The "pull chit out of a bag" mechanism is something I always enjoy, and the push-your-luck feeling and sett collection part was also really cool. Calling this an auction game is in some part misleading, since the other parts of the game are just as important. I usually don't enjoy auction games, but this one I liked.

Update: I realized after my first play how much I kept thinking about the game and had to buy it. It is easily an 8 now, and could rise. Plays great with two.

I will never turn down a quick game of Ra.

RATING: 8
Fun game from Reiner Knizia about developing your own personal ancient Egyptian civilization over several epochs. You really do get a sense that you're creating a culture in this one. While I'm not a huge fan of the auction element found in it, I do enjoy the tension that can come about when you really don't want that Ra tile to appear. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Ra is a classic thoroughly deserving of a reprint, one of the few good Knizia introductory games.  The only potential complexity concerns the scoring.  In fact, I would say this is the ultimate introductory game as it blends simplicity with a distinctively Euro feel.  Often introductory games, while decent family games, fail to provide the crucial stepping stone implied by the term "introductory."  Ra is vintage Knizia and lets face it, any solid gamer will play quite a few of his games.

Of course, particularly appealing is the ability to blame any loss on the luck of the tile draws, when more likely lack of piety towards Ra is the culprit.  Actually, luck forms the only significant flaw.  Playing a perfect game never ensures a win.  Skillful play mitigates the randomness, but Ra remains to its core a game of luck. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very interesting bidding mechanism, with a bit of press-your-luck thrown in.  Quick play time is an added bonus.  There's a lot to keep track of and the decisions on when and how much to bid are always interesting (and agonizing).

I have never won this game, and yet I still play.

RATING: 10
How can a game with so few options be so good? I've been trying to figure this question out since the first time I played Ra. This game just works. Thats it. For whatever reason it just does. The "push your luck" part of the game is a ton of fun for everyone playing whether your the one drawing or one of the three other people screaming for a red tile to come up. And there is always that one person who has the 1, 4, and 6 suns who yells RA!! every freaking turn. To add, it takes 5 minutes to learn and 20 minutes to play making it my gateway game of choice.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Great Game.  It is easy to teach and for new players pick up.  It is another Euro classic and I would say if You had to have one of 5 games for other people this is one of them.  

It is well constructed and pretty to look at and some players have made useful tools etc to make its theme even pop more than it can.  It is fun with a group that gets into the game and ends up chanting Ra!..Ra!...Ra!!... In hopes that some hapless architect of ancient egypt struggles to make his place in history-- maybe that person will draw a turn-stopping tile crushing their hopes, and furthering your success...

It is referred to as a bidding game sometimes, but I also think of it a resource management.  In the sense that even money is traded for... other money.  

Points are scored in 3 phases(epics) and then there are special groups of tiles gathered through the epics that cmoe into play at the end game.  You want to get combinations/collections of tiles that are randomly drawn from a bag and you want to avoid being left without other various tiles or it will cost you.  Do you bid now to get some tile to prevent loss or do you hold out trying to glean more tiles....?

This game is good to teach some non-gamers as the learning curve would be short for newbies.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Like this game a lot. As there are several things to look at through the game.
You need to have a good picture of your own and your opponents tiles to be able to see when you need to call RA. Also important is to see that you have good value Sun tiles to be able to react and act in the next epoch.

Very fun, and quick to learn. One needs to know the scoring rules by heart of otherwise it can be hard to bid on the right tiles.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is my favorite Knizia bidding game. It includes several scoring options to balance and consider, diminishing the element of 'luck of the draw.' Need to compromise some element of your scoring strategy or you will lose the opportunity to score anything. Theme is actually present with the invoking of Ra implying his favor for blessings upon the four developments. This may be a bit shallow, but it works for an ancient Egyptian theme. The game also includes beautiful graphics with the tiles and on the board itself.  Very tough decisions when it comes to deciding whether to call or participate in an auction, and how much to commit when wanting only to bluff. Really scales well from 3 - 5 players. Love it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Another Knizia that is actually fun to play!  Woohoo!  And it's an auction game!  Well, kind of an auction game - I'd call this an evaluation game first and foremost.  It works good for two, and has a nice press-your-luck element, thanks to the random Ra tiles.  This one seems deep, but is on the light side, thanks to the randomness of the draw.  You basically have one kind of decision to make, but mulling over when to grab and when to let it ride is quite fun and tense.  Definitely deserving of its reputation, and I can see why this fit into the Alea big box series quite well (although we have the recent RG reprint, sans numeral, sadly).  As the only other evaluation game we'd really played was Medici vs. Strozzi (also a Knizia, and a game that plays like a bag full of ball bearings... to the face), this has redeemed the concept for us.  Good, solid stuff.

RATING: 8

Update II:  Have taught my daughters (10- and 8-year-olds) to play.  All liked it, had fun, they did OK.

Ra sat on a shelf for years, untouched, and now it is has come to enjoy a rebirth.  Good news for other untouched games.

RATING: 7
Another alea game that started out seeming pretty good but ended up as a true classic. Has that combination of fairly simple rules and straightforward gameplay that masks a great deal of subtlety. Any designer but Knizia, and it would probably turn out that there was a single strategy that was stronger than the rest, but with Knizia you can count on incredibly fine balance. Great game with huge replay value. I believe this is the ultimate auction game.

My only compaint about Ra is that I think the luck of the draw gets a touch out of control with 5 players (with 5 players, it probably rates an 8 instead of a 10). I would generally prefer fewer players, and with 3 players, I think Ra is utterly brilliant.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The Shut Up & Sit Down video review made this sound interesting, but I wasn't sure if this would be too heavy for the group. For Sale seemed about right.

This was $60 at Dice House Games. I like the idea of the game, but that was too much for me. We already had the new version of Modern Art, so that seemed excessive. I found a used copy of the Dutch version (that has wooden sun tokens!) and ended up buying that. I need to create English cheat sheets for this game.

We had two bad plays, where I was trying to figure out the rules on my phone while I was trying to teach using the hints in Dutch on the board. It didn't work. After I made notes, though, teaching the game was relatively easy, and everyone understood the game rather quickly.

I like the bidding, and how the tile that you bid can be won by someone else later in the game. I also like that the bids are constrained to the three or four sun tokens that you have.

The game plays really differently at 3p vs. 4p. I didn't adjust my bidding for the 4p game, and I was out relatively early, without enough points. I haven't played a 5p game yet.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of the most elegant games ever designed. Normally I dislike once-around bidding, but it just works so incredibly well in this game. Ra is chock full of agonizing, tough decisions. The bidding sun mechanism is fantastic; it adds more depth to the game and gives it exactly the right amount of strategy. The scoring might be a little overwhelming at first but it quickly becomes second nature. A fantastic game.

Edit: You know, this game has REALLY stood the test of time for me. It was one of my first gaming loves and is one of the few games I'm just as excited to play almost a decade later. It is more interactive than most auction games, as each decision you make requires you to consider what everyone else has and is likely to do. It moves at a great pace and is SUCH a meaty game for the 45 minutes it takes, without ever being overwhelming. This earned its 10 long, long ago.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
As a fan of games that involve constant valuation and pushing your luck, this one holds a special place in my heart; I have yet to play another auction game that encapsulates those two aspects in such a pure and elegant way.  The various ways in which different sets of tiles are scored keep the valuations interesting, but this does mean that the game can feel very mathematical at times (as do many of Dr. Knizia's other games).  The unpredictable length of each epoch, determined by the Ra track, underlies the push-your-luck aspect of the game.  Of course, planning ahead to acquire the sun tiles one needs for subsequent epochs is another strategic consideration.  The Egyptian theme is irrelevant, but it does provide the context for the nice art on the components and the Ra figure.  Deservedly one of the classic Euro auction games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
For the playing time, can't get any better. I love games that force you to think offensively and defensively on every turn, and the gambling element always keeps things fresh. 

Knizia is amazing about giving you a very limited decision (pull tile, play god, call Ra) and creating agonizing tension and huge depth and replayability. If someone who never played a Knizia were to ask me for a recommendation that gave them a good idea of everything he was about, Ra would probably get the nod.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.25
Fantastic auction game! Every gamer needs to own an auction game, and this one is a pretty neat one - currently it's my favorite auction game because it's so easy to teach and learn, yet it's certainly NOT easy to actually win and there are many paths to victory... It's hands down one of the most elegant designs I've ever come across. Few rules + tough decisions = winning combination!

I think it's a cool mechanic that you have to estimate the value of the different tiles to you and your opponents - and this estimation changes with every single tile drawn! And even though you don't want to win an auction, it might be good to invoke Ra anyway just to avoid other players getting too many tiles. This is especially true when you have low suns, which are actually quite good even though new players seem to overlook this fact. After a couple of plays they start to be much more aggressive with their lower suns and invoke RA a lot more. Players with the highest suns sometimes seem to be too greedy because they know they can get all of the tiles, but that might actually be a disadvantage if the other players play smartly and constantly invoke RA!
I even won a 3p game once with 73 points even though I had suns 2, 3, 4 and 5 (!!!) in the second era!

There are tons of ways to score points, and there is obviously no winning strategy. You can go for nile tiles, but if you never get a flood you're screwed. But it's all about taking (calculated) chances and evaluating the risks. Sure, you can be unlucky and draw some tiles which doesn't do anything for you but help your opponent, or you can draw a disaster tile when you were considering to invoke Ra instead, making the tiles for auction less desirable. But it's all about estimating the values of the current tiles (only the monuments you need to "plan" a little ahead for). 

I've seen and heard some describe Ra as a "luck fest" - and in all honesty it couldn't be further from the truth! Yes, it’s not chess; I admit that there is some luck when you’re drawing the tile, but it isn’t that crucial – because it’s only one tile, and then you need to evaluate the new situation. And also because the tile you have drawn is not added to your own player board or something like that as in other games, but it’s added to the center tableau where everybody can win it… So the luck is actually not that significant, and that’s why some people seem to consistently win this game, which they wouldn’t ever do if it had as much luck as some claim...

Oh, and just a tip; don't ever let a player sit back with two bids while everybody else has used their suns if there are 3-4 open Ra spaces left (I've seen it a couple of times); unless this player is unlucky, he can draw and get at least 8 tiles before the era is over. Speaking of this, I absolutely love the tension of the Ra tiles as you never know when the era/epoch is going to end! I've seen people win and lose because of 4 Ra tiles being pulled from the bag in a row, but it's not too common. The tension is delightful!

Finally, Ra plays very across all player counts, even with 2 (!), and it plays in less than an hour (around half an hour with 3 players or so, and it works surprisingly well with 2 players for an auction game), so I think Ra deserves its high rating!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Of the games I love, it is especially difficult for me to explain my enjoyment of this one.  It doesn't have the streamlined elegance of a Sackson game, nor of Dorra's best.  And you'd think that the multitude of scoring mechanisms would be clunky.  But this game hums along at a brisk, easy pace, filled with engaging tension.  The sun-bidding mechanism is the game's most elegant feature.  The tempo is fun; draw a tile, and pass the bag.  The push-your-luck element of each round prompts head slaps and loud groans, while the luck element never feels too great.  The game isn't simple, but it nevertheless plays very simply and fascinatingly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Ra is the first game (along with Metropolys!) I rated a 10. I love auction games, and for me, Ra is the definitive auction game. It's not "a game with an auction round," the auction is the game, and Ra produces brinksmanship and interaction more than most other auction games.

There's three things that make Ra work incredibly well. You're not bidding money. Instead, you have three or four "suns" of different value, so you are limited in your bids. None of this bid around the table "twelve... thirteen... fourteen... um... fifteen. Sixteen? Sixteen." A bid in Ra is once around the table, and you better make it count.

The other thing about Ra is that, as players collect all the different range of tiles, players end up viewing the value of the tile set up for auction much differently. Some tiles relatively useless to one player are crucial to another. This produces lively auctions and table talk. 

...and lastly, each one of the three rounds ends when X number of Ra tiles are drawn, which creates a "game clock" that winds down at different paces. The result is a press-your-luck ending and pressure for those players with remaining bids.

My only possible knock on Ra is that it's relatively themeless. The Egyptian theme has little to do with the mechanics, but it adds an aura of "classiness." Given that this fantastic game wraps up in 45 minutes or less, I expect I'll be playing this one for as long as I play Euro games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
This game combines an auction mechanic, set collection, and press-your-luck.  It's worth noting that it's not a typical auction.  You will have three different values you can bid which could be something like 1, 9, and 13 or 3, 5, and 12.  You can only bid these specific amounts, which can make the auctions interesting.
The game plays fast.  Even with 5 players, it won't last an hour once you are familiar with the rules.  Perfect game for those nights that finish too early to start playing filler, but you don't have the time to start a new 2 hour game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The use of the sun markers for the auction creates a very novel feel to the bidding in this game. The fact that you also inherit the current chip is an interesting twist. I also like the superfluous substantial wooden components.

But the part that makes this game genius is the economy of the Ra tiles as you go from epoch to epoch. The relative scarcity of 'good tiles' dwindles and the tension grows and grows. In the end it can get very exciting. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Best. Auction game. Ever.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is very solid, the different scoring mechanisms mesh well and offer the kind of variety necessary to keep my interest with a nice balance between short term profit and long term investments. The auction 'sun' mechanic is also innovative as it allows one to cash in low suns for future rounds, or to screw the opposition and force them to 'overpay' for smaller lots with a lucrative tile or two in them. It's a rare auction game that scales down well to 3 players, and this manages to do that, and also to have a workable 2 player variation as well. Only weighs in at medium, but it's hard to find a better game at that weight that plays in only an hour. This is all about timing: when to invoke Ra, when to keep drawing, how much to pay for a given lot, I admire how everything meshes together. 

I used to dither back and forth about whether I liked this or Modern Art more, and MA is currently in the lead simply because I've mildly burned out on Ra. For virgins, this is the one you should pick up if you like pushing your luck and number crunching, and is probably a little less susceptible to newbie game weirdness. I think that it lacks the psychology and interesting hand management aspects of Modern Art, but it largely makes up for it with the wild and wooly fun of the tile draw, especially because of the disaster tiles and the way they impact the value of auctions...not to mention the always present threat that the round will end before you want it to!

This is a very solid title, and is highly recommended to any gamer who likes pure auction games.

RATING: 9
Feels like a classic. [-]I'm terrible at auction games as I never realise what's valuable to me, but out of all of them I enjoy this the most and happy to keep playing even though I always lose! Perhaps I'm hoping I'll get better at it one day...[/-]

Time to update this, as I quite often do win now or come close. I still love this and like it more and more every time I play. It might even make a 10 one day. The only niggle is whether the strategies are too limited and linear, but it doesn't really factor all that much, because the main thrust of the game (and I guess the main reason why it might put people off) is the constant evaluating of your and your opponents' hand, and the relative value of the tiles available. I love that tension. The feeling of calling Ra or bidding out of place just so you force an oponent into a decisiosn they really didn't want to make is delicious.

I'm still terrible at open bidding but closed economies like this suit me fine, as it's much easier to focus on value. Plus the set collection aspect appeals, and it's very easy to teach.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ra is a bit of a pendulum in terms of my appreciation for it. At first I found it cool, then I went through a phase of 'average', and now its star is slowly rising again. But I'll add a very important 'but' here: you should always play with people who know what they are doing, and know the basic strategies. Then, and [i]only[/i] then, does the game stand a chance of showing what it's capable of. In other words: don't take games with newcomers too seriously until they've grown a decent feel of how the game works. (I should probably be more lenient with other games where this is a factor, too.)

Ra is a auction game with very clean and lean mechanics, and thus allows the players to fight it out amongst themselves. The scoring is typical of Knizia: convoluted like hell, and thus a source of confusion for the newbies. You must correctly assess what is on display to be able to decide what to do. Subject-wise, this game is pointless, but it provides for a nice background which still seems to work. Presentation-wise, I prefer the BSW-interface as it's clearer what other players have amassed so far. There is no genuine turn angst save in a few special cases: the decision space is rather limited, after all, and in most cases, easily collapses into a single decision. But don't let this fool you: playing this game well depends on a lot of exceedingly subtle factors, and mastering those will keep you busy for quite a while. The fact that the original alea- and 999 Games-editions function exceedingly well with a 2 player-variant which now has been promoted to an official ruleset should increase the amount of table time in any household.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Ra was one of those earlier euro style games that have stood the test of time.  I own the 1999 release which is slightly different from the newer itteration of the game.  This is a game of press your luck.  Each player is trying to accumulate various tiles that score points on each of the three major rounds.  Most of the tiles go away with the ravages of time other than monument tiles and a few other types of tiles.  The cool part of the game is the bidding mechanism.  Greed is also strong in this game as players jockey for wanting more and more useful tiles before declaring RA.  But look out, the round may end prematurely if the wrong tiles are pulled randomly out of the bag potentially leaving players with unused bidding tiles at the end of a round.  This game is a lot of fun and has good replayability.  It is not deep, but also plays well with the Egyptian theme per the game title for design.  This was one of my first euro games collected and it gets played two or three times a year even now in 2013.  Ra has made my top 50 list of euro style games of all time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Wow, Asmodee, $59.99 MSRP and with their enforced  price floor?. 
Was $40 MSRP back in the day, now with very cheap components $59.99 aka $60.00?  Unbelievable...

They seem to just jack up prices to get they max off to hit near what the MSRP should be.  If I am remembering correctly, their price floor would put a hard limit of a sale price of $48.00 on this game. This is the absolute lowest price with a price floor of 20 percent. So Admodee's MSRP on the box = (what should be the real MSRP) plus 20 percent? Google "floor price". It basically a business model that ops to ignore supply and demand, setting a price point that is higher then where the two variables meet. It opts to lost sales, making up the lost via of lower units sold but at higher prices. Floor Pricing forces buyers out of the market. 

Not worth $35 tops to buy, for what you get in the box. Look at the components vs the older versions.. Factor in this game play isn't earth shattering. 

Will never buy any game that goes thru their distribution since they all get hit with that price floor. Price floor? This is got to hurt small shops that stock their games, and they can't clearance them off the selves when the desire wanes? My opinion, it hurts everyone except high volume online retailers. This will force out lower volume retailers. 

At the end of the day this is just a board game and no way would I get $59.99 worth of pleasure out of this thing, in fact, it would piss me off at the thought of paying that for this. Just so many more better games out there to spend $60.00 bucks on then this. Yeah, I now rate games based on price vs what I get out of it. 

Got rid of my original copy of the original game, payed something like $25 dollars for it. Sold it for $20.00. For the game play, about what it was worth.

If this  hobby keeps going into the deep $60.00 plus, going to just take up golf instead... it would be cheaper.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
2016 Secret Santa
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This twist on a standard auction game limits players to only three successful bids each round.  And in return you get the bidding tile that was used to win the prior auction.  Players work to collect tiles in various areas, struggling not to be the lowest in a few of them.

On the one hand I appreciate the unique bidding mechanism, and that sometimes the auctions are dangerous to win because of disasters.  What isn't apparent to me just yet is how players can stay out of the hole when they do poorly early in the game.  A few -5 penalties are devastating if you just couldn't win the right tiles.

I'm curious, but not fully convinced this game is as great as I've heard.  Modern Art remains the superior auction game for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Components: Sturdy, functional components, with great wooden sun tokens. I'm still having trouble differentiating between the different monuments. The Uberplay edition has red x's on the tiles that I keep; the x's should be on the tiles that I throw away each round; makes it very confusing to explain to players each turn.

Experience: The auction works very well, with each lot having advantages and disadvantages for each player. I am particularly impressed by the mechanism of swapping out sun tokens. There is great tension as players budget their tokens, often calling Ra on small sets, trying to get bargains rather than letting the player with the highest valued sun token just build up a monster lot.

First Played: 2004-05-17
Last Played: 2014-01-25
Plays (8):
3 players: 4
4 players: 3
5 players: 1

RATING: 8
I'm always very unsure what to make of Reiner Knizia, he has designed some good games, but many (often highly regarded by others) I just don't like. Maybe it is his penchant for auction games, which are not my favourite things. In this case the system where you can only win a set number of auctions and everyone knows what the others can bid is brilliant and because of that I think it's his best game, the only one of his that I can't envisage turning down a game of.

ɅV

RATING: 9
One problem with many auction games is figuring out the "true" value of what you are buying.  That problem is not a problem in Ra.  You don't have much choice in what to bid, and different sets are worth different amounts at different times to different players.  Superb game, probably the best of Knizia's auction games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The best auction game. By reducing the amount of information a player needs to process during a bidding round, making the value of what's being bid on variable or risky to varying degrees, and limiting the amount one can bid, the game avoids nearly all the pitfalls of other auction games (brinksmanship, snowballing wealth) and injects tension into every decision. It's also the perfect length.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The game is also very much about pushing your luck, and the random tile draws are a part of that.

RATING: 8.74614
A beautiful auction mechanic, making for quick auctions where the 'currency' you bid with is almost self-correcting (those with horrible numbers can bid purely to get a slightly-better number).

Set collection seems well balanced.

Game contains fun moments: great to watch Mark drawing tiles when the last player in, gambling on getting a great 'collection' before the round-ending tile arrises.

Plays fast, simple with interesting choices. Light but fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Best auction game ever and an all-time favorite.  Each player only has three purchases of bids in each of three epochs, so you have to make sure you get the most bang for your egyptobucks, while making sure your opponents pay through the nose. There's lots of playing chicken as well, trying to force the price up without getting stuck with something you don't want. The best part of it is how each set of tiles up for bid is worth a different amount to each player, so you need to be aware of your opponent's tiles at all time. Fantastic game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.2
One of the best auction games ever.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is a bidding game with a pasted-on Egyptian theme.  Bid and collect tiles for scoring, but once you've successfully bid on three auctions, you're done for the round.  Tension in that you only get one chance to bid during each auction--there's no "upping" your bid.  Furthermore, there's a push-your-luck element included so players don't hoard their bidding tiles.  Good bit of fun and strategy packed into one hour.  Excellent game that's fun for gamers and non-gamers alike.  

Good game, but the Rio Grande production quality sucks with the cardboard tiles--I prefer the "European" quality of cardboard.  Also, there was no good reason to enlarge the board and pieces, as RGG did.  Get the Uberplay version.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
sweet game for non-hardcores, with lovely artwork that is fun to handle, and nice mix of serious game theory and lighthearted play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Knizia's most accessible pure auction game. Easy analysis of each bid, thanks to the following: bidding currency (almost) different from winning criteria, fixed maximal number of bids, perfectly known bidding strength of each player and once around biddind method. 
On the other hand, the value of each set is quite hard to evaluate properly.

Fast, appealing and really interesting. Worth the hype.  

(N. players: 3>4>5, due to the increasing lack of control)

RATING: 8
Man, this is a dang fine piece of work.  Pure perfect main mechanic, tons of ways to score, maybe a little off in how one person can finish a round way before anyone else, but that is made up for by the thrill of the final bid holder playing against the clock to steal as much as possible.  How much is a bid worth when you have five scoring oppurtunities, next round's bid, and the sun clock to consider?  Every auction is interesting.

RATING: 9
One of the better auction games I've played.  I always want to play this game...even though I rarely win. Good game for newbies that frown upon being at a disadvantage.  A first time player has as good a chance to win as someone who's played 20 times.  I find myself upgrading this from an 8 to a 9.  I have played this excellent game for years and years.  it's easy to teach and is a great game to pull out when you have a group of well-versed gamers.  Almost everyone likes it to some extent and is willing to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ra was another game introduced to me by Eric in one of our weekend get togethers.

I like Ra. Despite my aversion to pure auction games, Ra did it quickly and elegantly enough to make it fun and interesting for me to play. I liked the push your luck aspect of calling Ra, and I liked the fact that you had to weight when, exactly, to use your bidding tiles instead of dealing out money for the auction. The set collection is pretty interesting too. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Excellent bidding game from Reiner Knizia that seems to produce acute anguish each time it hits the table. Players bid via simple auction mechanics on tiles that are drawn randomly from the bag. At the end of each round victory points are awarded (or lost!) based on your purchases. You are very detached from the theme of ancient Egypt, but who cares when the game play is as good as this. A game I'll always play.

RATING: 8
Great auction game that works well with two players. Many things about this game are genius. The game has a lot of depth because each bid/decision has it's pros and cons that must be considered, but it's simple and quick enough that it's not overwhelming. It's not just about deciding what to bid, but also when to start an auction. Plus the blind tile draw allows for some push-your-luck decisions that I love. Passing the draw bag works well to remind players that it's their turn, so the game subtly keeps players focused.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Neat mechanics. I think more plays will increase my rating.

2011/01/04: Better game than I originally thought, though we did not play with the correct rules. I only used 1 god tile in 3 games, because we were drawing tiles first every turn.  Definitely need to play with correct drawing rules, and remembering when the auction row is full, the forced Ra does not have to be purchased.

2011/01/24: Mary killed us with monuments. Aaron barely scored the entire game.  Game still feels like it moves too quickly. We might play again and remove some Ra tiles.

2011/02/01: Realising that the last Ra tile drawn in each epoch does not trigger an auction changes the 'push-your-luck' aspect of this to an acceptable level. I'm raising the rating to 8.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
There is a lot of room for skillful play in the chaos of the draw. Essentially the game gives out victory points for poker hands... but the cards needed to build your poker hands are auctioned off in lots. Fun, convoluted combos make each player ask themselves 'How much are these tiles worth to ME?' The press-your-luck element is another clever addition, as players keep adding more tiles to the auctions. Genius.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Salvaged the wooden betting tiles from a cheap copy of the slightly inferior priests of ra, their addition improves this already gorgeous edition. This is an amazing game, being both simple and quite deep. It's an auction game that I imagine people who don't like auction games can get behind. It's fast, and quite addictive. I play the app often, and could almost imagine playing this in a casino. Its also very good with two, which is unusual for an auction game. It's my favourite of the Knizia auction games. Medici is simpler and more pure, modern art eclipses both, but only with the right crowd, this is the smartest and sleakest of the bunch. I like the Egyptian themeing, the new tiles look fab ( though I can imagine legibility issues may have been raised). I see myself as being  more of an Ameritrash gamer really, but these older games, euros before that name existed are where it's at really.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After some more plays, I'm bumping this one to a 10!  Ra is an outstanding game, and my favorite Knizia auction.  I really enjoy the bidding for lots mechanism, as it means you're never bidding on quite the same thing from game to game.  I love the amount of control you can wield over the other players through strategic calling of Ra and well placed bids (Ra would be an excellent tutorial on the importance of position for poker players).  You are definitely directly challenging your opponents, and yet because of the bidding mechanism, it doesn't feel as confrontational as it is (people feel as though they've screwed themselves when you manage to back them into a corner).  The game is very quick for one with so much open information.  Ra's surprisingly good with 2 players using the variant posted here.

THE SPARK: No other game I have played lets you force tough decisions on your opponents like this one.  It is delicious

UPDATE Sept2012: Played this again after a long respite.  The shine has not diminished one bit.  10!!!

RATING: 10
Easily one of my favorite games, and a prime example of why I respect Knizia so much.

Set collection done right: the different sets are very distinct from one another, and play out in interesting ways as the rounds proceed.

Auctioning done extremely right: This is, by a long shot, the absolute best auctioning mechanic I've seen. Three values you can use to bid with, replacing it with the 'spare' value each time. It's quicker than rounds of +1 and way more interesting.

Using this stunning auction mechanism to obtain fascinating sets? My word, have you got me sold.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Blech.  Ra is a popular game, but I can't see why.  It's an auction game without the auction.  Most of the decisions are pretty brain-dead, as there's always one person at the table who has the highest single number, and they get final say if the lot is something they want.  Now, they do have to decide if it's worth it, and the fact that you're swapping suns means you have to consider whether you want that new number next turn.  But, in general, the game is super random and irritates me no end.

If you're the last one in, you can go one-on-one with the tile bag, and potentially get a huge haul with just one sun.  But this just turns it into a push-your-luck exercise where the rest of the table gets to watch helplessly.  And the rest of the rounds can degenerate into maneuvering to be the player in this position.  A large chunk of it seems to be calling auctions on marginal lots to try and drive out the other players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Ra is great. There's a little more to explain than other Knizia auction games, so I've had a harder time getting it to the table.

While the limited sun tokens make bidding a fun puzzle to solve, they reduce your ability to make more arbitrary valuations compared to something like Medici. I like Medici's bidding a little better because you're bidding with victory points, too.

RATING: 10
UPDATE: The more I play this game, the more I love it. I'm not sure if it's Knizia's best game ever, but it's pretty darn close. ANOTHER UPDATE: Yeah, it's his best game ever. So there.

I think that this is perhaps the perfect auction game: easy to explain, looks great, and always keeps you guessing. I like the fact that you have limited amounts to bid -- this makes the game run faster than a typical auction game in my opinion and makes for some interesting tactical decisions.

I really need to push Ra more in my game group.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a great auction game that's very easy to set up, teach and play.  The scoring takes newbies a little getting used to however.  If you print out a player mat with the scoring rules on the mat, it makes things much easier.  Ra makes me want to try the other Knizia auction games.  I think the best mechanism in Ra, is that the person that initiates the once-around auction is the last person to make a bid and if nobody else bids you have to take the item.  I never thought I would like a game that just revolves around bidding after having played Fist of Dragonstones but Ra is so elegant in what it does that that I can't see anyone disliking it.  No one that I've introduced it to has disliked it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Seems like I learn something new every time I play it. I like it much better than Modern Art (another game in the auction trilogy), just because it gets painful to juggle/guess everyone's "income" in Modern Art compared to this... plus people play like asses when they play Modern Art.

Has been replaced by Medici as my favorite pure auction game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Do not dismiss this as a simple bidding game. It is very unique. If you win the bid, you win the previous bidding marker, and your bidding marker gets added to the items for the next auction. You are trying to collect various items that score in all sorts of ways (sets, most of, most different, etc). There is also an unknown amount of time to get what you want. If you are too greedy, you might get burned.

[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/115037]SEE MY REVIEW[/url]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This game is a lot of fun. Print off the player sheets before you play this one, I don't think that the Uberplay version would be too good without them. 

8 to 9. This game is really interesting. Have played (not logged) more BSW plays than I have real plays. There's a lot going on in this game and the more I play it, the more I like it. With the tile draw, there's a substantial luck aspect that gives the game its legs. You definitely need luck on your side to be in contention, but skill is what will put a player over the top.  

Many plays on BSW not logged. (25-30)

9 to 7. It's still a really interesting game, but after about 30 BSW plays I feel that the game has a little too much luck involved. Too many times I have been out of the game after the first round based on the assigned tiles and how the auctions proceed. It's still an amazing auction game, but a lot of the magic is gone for me. 

I really hate how this game can just hand over the victory to a player sometimes. Sure, he or she can really get themselves in a good position with a well-placed bid but I feel like this game can really hose a player. That being said, I still want to play all the time. 

7 back to 9. Won 3 of 4 on BSW the other day (when up to that I was probably taking last quite a few times) the game just clicked in my head and I have that newfound love for it again.

Pilar y Jorge se descuelgan y solo Charlie aguanta mi tirón epro de modo insuficiente;_ gano con 48 puntos.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is a brilliant game which I'm sure will see plenty of play with my groups. It's so easy to pull out and get going, and it's short enough to play multiple times in a session. It's super easy to explain and for people to pick up, yet there's more to it than a simpler set collection game like Sushi Go. I love the subtle head games you get into with your opponents, yet you're rooting for the same thing a lot of the time. It's all about carefully timing your tactical use of auction calling in order to get the most out of the situation or give your opponents the least. I like the level of player interaction in the game as well. 

You can get into a situation where there's a lot of Ra tiles being drawn, basically one after another, but at least that's often unhelpful for everyone instead of just 1 person getting screwed. I've also noticed that scores can vary pretty wildly between players. I also replaced the included bag with a larger bag which I think is more appropriately sized for the large number of tiles in the game.

I purchased the old Alea edition because I was concerned about readability of the current edition's tiles. I also prefer the wood components to the current edition's cardboard & plastic. I do wish there was a middle ground edition, between utilitarian readability and beautiful design. For the $35 that I payed second-hand, I feel like I got a great deal, but I do think the MSRP of the current edition is too high for a game like this. That plus the design decisions which increased demand for the older editions is inflating the second-hand value of the more reasonably priced previous editions. I can't really fault the game or the designer for that though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Not just my favorite Knizia game -- my favorite game period!  It is the perfect balance of every aspect of gaming.  A wonderful jewel that I never tire of playing.

RATING: 9
Love it.  My favourite auction game.  

Your first one or two of plays of this are probably not going to be great fun, until you have more of a feeling of the potential value of the sets on the block.  Probably my favourite Knizia game.  From a very limited choice of actions (being pretty much [draw tile | call auction] or [raise bid | leave auction]), come a large set of interesting decisions.  

Also, nice components with good art.  Portable, particularly if you don't care about the board.  

I recommend printing off a player mat for each player from BGG, to give newbies an aid in visualising what it is they're collecting and what might come out.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Ra is an auction game with some twists.  I usually don't enjoy auction games much, but this one works for me.  It has a unique "opportunity cost" mechanism and a "push your luck" aspect which rises it above the general monotony of auction games to make it more thrilling.  You bid on a whole row of tiles (which may contain negative tiles that destroy part of your tableau). On your turn, you can play a tile to the auction row, snipe a tile from the auction with a "God tile," or shout "Ra!" at the top of your lungs while banging the statue on the table, triggering an auction.

There are 3 epochs, with scoring at the end of each for most types of tiles. You start with three sun tokens of various amounts (no two players have the same sun token amounts) as your money for bidding.  When you win an auction, you exchange your token for the one in the middle (which begins the game as a "1"). The token you take is placed upside down in front of you, and becomes your money to bid in the next epoch. The one you've placed is now up for grabs as part of the auction. 

Meantime, even if nobody is yelling "Ra," tiles with Ra on them appear and are placed on a track, triggering auctions. When the Ra track is full, the epoch is over and nobody gets the tiles currently on the auction track. So if you keep waiting for the auction track to fill, you may lose your chance for any tiles at all. 

To add to the fun, some of the tiles stay in your tableau from epoch to epoch, and some are removed from the game each epoch. As you lose points if you have the least or none of certain disappearing tiles, you have to keep working to get more every epoch (and can't just concentrate on building monuments -- which stay in your tableau and are scored at the end).

If you're an auction fan, you should definitely get this game. And if your friends are NOT, then you should doubly get this game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I enjoy this one more every time I play.

RATING: 7
I really like the auction mechanic in this where you bid an amount (sun) and then that gets added to the middle and is part of the next auction. This makes for interesting decisions i.e. I REALLY need that tile but I only have a 13 left to bid with... I don't really want an opponent gaining such a high bidding power.

Push your luck aspect is nice because you could win big or it could bite-you-in-the-ass and you effectively end up a round behind.

Several aspects returning to the box each epoch is interesting as it helps to maintain competition for the tiles throughout the game.

Sold in 2016.

RATING: 6.89

[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geekbuddy.php3?action=doanalyze&groupid=4204&B1=Analyze&gameid=12]Ratings[/url]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Pros
-Fairly streamlined push your luck and set collection game with solid auction mechanics
-As you have only a limited number of bids each round (a total of only 12ish bids in the whole game), each bid requires a lot of thought
-Semi-unpredictable round ends keeps the game tense at all times (will someone outbid me, will this round come to an end before I get something good etc)

Cons
-Game can be frustrating (and possibly punishing) when you predict incorrectly/push your luck too much/get unlucky
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
With more plays (with an AI) I've changed my opinion of the game. Ra's scoring does make sense thematically, and the auctions are quite unique - it's been said they are more like tricks in a trick-taking game.

Duration: This is a medium Euro - fairly quick if players don't ponder too long.
Design: Lots of pieces; you need to understand the scoring before you gain an appreciation of the game. The game scales well over different player counts.
Strategy: There are several different scoring paths that make auction valuation asymmetric.
Components: Decent pieces, tiles, board.
Theme: Egypt isn't my thing but the theme is well integrated into the somewhat artificial foundation.

RATING: 8
[Auction, Egyptian] {3P:9, 4P:7, 5P:5} The premiere pure auction game along with its sibling, Modern Art. The fun factor wears down after a lot of plays, but it's still got enough staying power to hit the table regularly. Part of the appeal is that it plays quickly. Another good thing is that people can yell "RAAAA!!!!" and blow off some stress. *** UPDATE: Still not as good as Modern Art, but still holding up well after many plays. Keeper, but not top shelf. *** UPDATE: You know what? RA is *better* than Modern Art. I doesn't seem to suffer from the 'weak/greedy player syndrome' that plagues Modern Art, and it remains interesting even after a truckload of plays. I underestimated this little gem. Here's hoping that the uberplay reprint pans out, and we can get our grubby gamer hands on a copy of RA that's identical to the alea except for the box! ***UPDATE: The problem with RA is that as the number of players increases, the control decreases substantially because it takes longer before your turn comes back around. In the interim all sorts of things can happen. I'll play with 4 if asked, but 5P is not certain. RA is still all kinds of excellent with 3P though, and it's one of the best games overall with that number of players. *** UPDATE: Acquired the 2005 uberplay reprint through the kindness of Wong Siow Hwee, who grabbed a copy from the FLGS and held it until I could get to Singapore to claim it. Thanks Siow Hwee!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25

*Great* gateway game that is also great for gamers. Just help players understand the scoring system and they will *get* it (and how great the balance of the suns are) by the end of the first epoch. 

Also works well with 2 in my opinion. It's different but it can be quite fun dueling for least and most. 

Theme was definitely pasted on, but it is a Knizia after all.

RATING: 7.5
My rating has gone up some with this game over time. Due to the high level of randomness, some games can be awful -- those stretches where Ra tiles come up like 5 times in 7 tiles or whatever are excruciating -- but skill is nevertheless an important factor. Most importantly, the core mechanics of the game are elegant, fun and quick, so this one gets a higher rating from me than I might have expected (being relatively luck averse). The 5P game, though, doesn't really work for me -- it's too many players chasing too few tiles over the course of a round to be fun; 3-4P is a significantly better experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A set collection bidding game with scoring rules that aren't really complicated but - as you might expect from Knizia - not as straightforward as other games. Tiles get randomly added to the pool that is auctioned off either when full or when one of the players decides to call on Ra. Then follows a single bidding round with the player who has started the auction bidding last. Each player has a limited set of bidding tiles with values from 1 to 12, and when you run out of tiles you're done for the round.

Lots of unusual twists but still easy enough to grasp to make a good auction gateway. That's not to say evaluating the lots is easy, though...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A quite funny auction/bidding game. The moment when only one player is getting tiles off the bag and the rest of players are invoking the Ra tiles to appear is superb. Very fast and intense. A must if you like biddings.

RATING: 7.1
2016
====

I love auction games, and so it might be no surprise that Ra is on this list also. Ra's auctions are more straight-forward than Karensansui's, but the additional management of sun tokens is quite a mind-frak. The additional set-collection aspect of Ra is what really puts it over the top for me, slightly edging out Karesansui.

[2014.11.26]
This game struck me on the first play, but we were all beginners.  I think I might rate it higher if I played a few with some players who knew that they were doing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Acquired 05/03/06

There are so many things I like about this game I don't know where to start.  Simple, simple rules that can be taught in five minutes.  But mastering the game...that could take some time.  Constantly challenges you to evaluate auction lots on the fly, taking into account variables such as time left in the epoch, the suns that opponents have left, what tiles are up for grabs that will help you (or them) the most...small touches keep you from getting too specialized.

Until I get a copy of E&T, this will be the finest Knizia in my collection.  And even then, I think I like this just as much.

Note to potential designers who want to make an auction game:  if you can't top this one (and likely you can't), don't even bother.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

I am left with the feeling that the reason this game is so highly rated is that it was out of print for so long.  I find that out of print games tend to suffer rating inflation that is never really corrected when they return to in-print status.  A fine game, but I don't find myself playing it much anymore - ended up selling my copy.
