=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An excellent take on an auction game.  The fact that each player is limited by their sun tiles and the Ra track filling up can make every turn a tense decision between drawing or calling Ra.  Bidding can take some thought if the value of the pot don't exactly match the value or your sun tiles.  And the last couple Ra spaces in each epoch usually turn into a game of chicken as the last player(s) try to squeeze the most out of the epoch before it ends.  In short, the game is filled with lovely, tense decisions but plays quickly and cleanly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A bit chaotic, but is a good auction game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I'm really surprised by how much I like this game. I've read about it before and it just seemed boring to me. I played it, and it had a nice amount of tension that came when bidding or worrying if others would take the tiles. There is a nice amount of randomness. Nobody knows when the Ra's will be drawn (when 8 are drawn, that round is over), so you have to use your suns wisely. Do I use my suns now in fear of the round running out? Do I save them later for better opportunities?

I also really like the system of the suns. Even if you have some really low ones, you are not screwed because of the way the system works. Everybody only has 4 suns to use per round, so if you have low ones, you can keep activating auctions to either force others to use their high ones or snatch them yourself. 

Very interesting game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
in shrink,  trade interest low

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have been interested in this game for quite some time now and have had it on my want list for a while to. When I finally got around to reading the rules I became even more intrigued. I would of liked to play it before I bought it, but the opportunity never arrived. So I decided to give it a shot and get a copy. I am pleased to say that it was a well worth purchase.

This is an excellent auction game with some really nice mechanics. It has a tiny bit of a luck element with the tile draw, but nothing so bad as to really interfere with the game. There can also be a bit of screw your neighbor involved, but again it's not overly done. The game is very well balanced and there are a few different strategies that can be used when playing. All of which could change at your next turn. This game really is a lot of fun.

The components are very well made and look good and fit the Egyptian theme well. I am a sucker for all things Egyptiian, so this goes over really well for me. I would highly recommend this game to everyone to at least try once or twice if the opportunity arises. I am also very glad that I took a chance on this game. It was well worth every cent and then some.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

2013-November:  A very challenging game, and popular with the family, but we just haven't had very many opportunities to play it.

RATING: 8.5
[b]Ra[/b] [i]Reiner Knizia 1999[/i] 
The best auction game ever, period, and my favourite Knizia´s design. Teach Ra is an easy task, learn it as well, but understand the mechanics, the interaction among the different tiles, and the timing of the bidding, is really a challenge. Ra needs less than one hour to be played among skilled gamers and a little bit more in the first games. But you should avoid Ra if you dont like auctions games. Its scalability is average: excellent with three, very good with four but I dont like it with five due to the lack of control over the bids. This is just a personal impression since many other players enjoy it with five as well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
RA is a fun game with some basic flaws.  The turn end can appear suddenly or take a long time.  There are sound strategies to follow in either of these cases but because you don't know when a turn will end you can only opt for a best guess.  Scoring happens in a variety of ways.  One of the most solid ways to score is to get an early lead in pharaohs and defend it, picking up other bonuses along the way.  Most of my wins and losses can be traced back to getting the pharaoh balance right or wrong.  Or the game just ending in a flurry.  A little more predictability would be nice.  Ra is still short (around one hour) and enjoyable, though.  I recommend it for light entertainment with a bit of thought and strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Update:  Lowered rating to a 9.

Would rather play any of the other three that I listed before this again.

RATING: 9
I love playing new games. It is very difficult for a game to get more than 10-15 plays in my collection. It is even more unusual for me to suggest playing games I have owned for over a year and played 20+ times. This still happens with Ra. I love it. Simple but with very tough decisions. I actually enjoy the rather arbitrary tile scoring system because of its variety (as opposed to tile collecting games like Hanging Gardens or Alhambra). The only reason it is not a 10 is that it can simply be excruciating to watch people over bid on tracks only to win because you draw 5 Ra tiles in a row to end the round.

RATING: 10
Great game!! One of the games that started the whole Game Boardness for me. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Seventeen plays. So clever and well-balanced it seems to have a life of its own. May be a bit bewildering at first, but after a couple of plays one acquires a feel for all the little nuances—how much the tiles are worth in a given circumstance, how quickly the end of an epoch can sneak up, when it's too late to worry about monuments, how likely one is going to find a flood in time for scoring, et cetera. One of the best middleweight games you're likely to find.

A few words about theme: the game is certainly abstract in the sense that what the players are doing has no real-world analogue; they take a god-like role and sort of vaguely improve the prestige of a dynasty. Or something. However, I don't think it's fair to be too dismissive of the game's thematic elements. If nothing else, it helps to inform the somewhat complicated scoring. The pharaohs represent socio-political power—a popularity contest on a grand scale—and so it's fitting that all that matters is coming in first (or at least not coming in last!). Agricultural improvements are lasting, but they only benefit you if the weather cooperates. Grand monuments are meaningless in the short term, but, since they remain even after the culture has died, they earn you a lot of posterity points at the end. As far as the civilization advances go, well, come on, your society has to invent SOMETHING or you're going to look like a total shlub. Ever forward, you know? Meanwhile, gold is always good, though it never seems to stick around.

All these elements sketch out a particular point of view of what the concept of "civilization" is all about, and so I think the game actually does provide fuel for the imagination. It's not so much a simulation as an essay with some nice pictures. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The best auction games involve lots of shouting. RA! Brilliant design that faces players with tough choices from beginning to end.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
2005 acquisition.  Beautiful game board and lovely artwork in the tiles.  Likely test driving this in a 2-player game soon.

Play 1 and a half 2-player game.  We used the 2-player variant suggested in the geek.  The first half game was aborted as we played it wrong, but once we got the rules right we started again.  I know there are some geeks who swear by how much fun they had playing this with 2 players, unfortunately, it just doesn't work for me with 2 players.  Everything we did seemed very mechanical.  I guess that's why it is recommended for 3-5 players.

I need to try this again with more people.

Increased my rating to 7.  3 players make the game much better than 2 but I think it depends on the people who you play the game with.  With less experienced players it may be difficult for them to judge when to start an auction and how much they should bid for the tiles.

RATING: 8
Interim rating of 9 after just 2 plays - it seems like a very simple, elegant game that has a lot more thought involved than it first appears.

Update: I've now played a few more times and my opinion has improved even more. As mentioned it is a simple yet elegant game, and it also has a lot of depth. On top of that it is great fun to play because the auction mechanism actually allows for a lot of player interaction and the opportunity to screw other people. Given that it clocks in at around 30-45 minutes as well and it plays equally well with 3, 4 or 5 I think it's definitely deserving of a 10 rating.

Edit: Still great and probably my go-to auction game but other new games mean it's lower down the pecking order when it comes to choosing what to play. Dropping to a 9 to reflect that.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Since bidding isn't at the top of my favorite game mechanisms list, it is a bit unlikely that I would so highly rate a game where bidding is a central core of the design. But, the key is that in Ra the bidding is not an opened ended determination of the right value to bid. Rather, you have 3 bid 'tokens' (suns) for a given epoch and the decision is on when to use them to obtain tiles from a finite but uncertain pool of opportunities. This transposition of the decision is a key element of the design. This is coupled with a multivariate scoring system that is applied at the end of each epoch and at the game end. In the usual Knizia way, the scoring has players attempting to cover multiple dimensions, but not enough opportunity to cover all the bases.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
I recognise that it's a good game - it's well thought out / designed and it's quick. However, I struggle with it a bit.

I think it's a bit cut-throat. I have faired badly in a few of the games I have played. 

There are 3 rounds (Epochs). Epochs can come to an end very swiftly. The most vexing aspect of the game is being left with tiles (especially high value ones) that you haven't been able to use before the epoch has ended.

Although I think I have finally got a handle on this game now I do have a tendency to hold out for a better deal that doesn't come up and then find that I have missed the out - annoying!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
(JAB Mars 2012) Un coup de coeur décidément. Un jeu d'enchères plutôt court assez simple et très interractif qui plait à toute catégories de personnes. C'est un jeu qui allie bien le hasard et la stratégie. Le seul petit côté négatif est que lorsque quelqu'un a misé tous ses soleils il doit attendre que tout le monde ait fini pour continuer à jouer. C'est un jeu qui a provoqué bien des fous rires et des stress euphoriques lors de mes expériences de jeux. C'est un jeu de gamble où on évalue le risque de piger un Râ et décréter une enchère qui mène vers la fin du jeu vs la probabilité de piger des tuiles intéressantes. Parfois on pousse sa luck: parfois on gagne, parfois on perd. Un excellent jeu pour tout le monde! Le thème du jeu est également bien présenté par le matériel du jeu. Ce jeu est tout à fait original et divertissant!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Finally got a chance to play this. I think I enjoyed it quite a bit more than anyone else I played with, which is a shame. I really need to play it a few more times, but I can already tell that there are multiple paths to victory here. I love that the "bad things" that happen don't just happen to you, you have to decide if you want to bid on them as well. And the auction mechanic of putting what you pay in the middle for the next auction is something I haven't ever seen before, and it works beautifully. I got complaints from other people about downtime and randomness, but I didn't see either one of those things being an issue. UPDATE: My rating has risen as I've played it more. I often don't like games where at the end you have to count everything up and see who won, but the mechanics of the game itself (mostly) make up for this drawback. I can't see it ever being in my top 10, but I would never want to part with it either.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is quite simply fun.  For a game with only 2-3 thing possible to do on your turn, there are a lot of tough decisions.  The best auction game there is.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I've played this game many times, and often win.  Also, I usually like Knizia games.  But for some reason, I don't really like this one.  Perhaps it's much more of a press-your-luck game than his other ones, because there is little control over the upcoming tiles.  I think I often win because I exit the auctions early -- I get what I want, and *don't* press my luck, while everybody else fights till the Ra track fills up.  Too much randomness kills the fun in many games for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I've only played Ra one time, but it has left a great impression on me.  One of my favorite things about board games is the multiple avenues you can achieve victory.  In Ra, having the highest score wins, but how you get there is entirely up to you.  Will you try and hoard monument tiles and play the long game, or will you try to get a million rivers/floods in the interim, ever so slowly adding your score up.  

A competitive game I wouldn't mind owning.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[Initial Impression: 8]
This is a fascinating auction game that contains multiple scoring mechanisms and some highly strategic options.  On each turn, the player either turns up a new tile (which will generally add to the value of the lot to be auctioned), steals a valuable tile (if in possession of a rare god tile), or calls an auction.  It can be very tricky to call an auction, as you have to decide whether you're in a position of strength to win the auction, or if in a position of weakness, whether you can force others to use their higher-value tiles to take an auction lot that isn't particularly valuable.  Call an auction too soon and you'll be stuck bidding on a low-scoring lot, call it too late and someone else will place a high bid to take the high-scoring lot from you.  The auction mechanism can be a bit wonky, as it is a once-around auction and each player starts with a predetermined set of tiles (essentially a convoluted way of making it possible for each player to win a certain number of auctions per round).  With many possible ways to score, it can be very difficult to value each lot, and every lot will hold a different value to each player, depending upon what they've acquired earlier in the game.  Catastrophe tiles, which will destroy some of your previously acquired tiles, can sometimes "poison" a lot, making it of negative worth to some players and positive worth to others.  There can also be a press-your-luck element if you are the only player remaining in a round, as you get to pull as many tiles as you want while hoping that you don't pull one that will end the round before you can take your guaranteed lot. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ra is a press-your-luck set collection/auction game with what was originally a unique auction mechanic, pre-Feld-ian punishment, and just a generally fun, interactive feel.

Players bid with a limited number of Suns to win sets of tiles, collecting to gain points before the round ends.

It's fairly cut and dried who would win each auction- if they want to- but the valuation of what would be gained and when it is time to strike is what really makes this game.

Sometimes its obvious what your opponents want, sometimes less so- and how you value the tiles/situation is what sets your bid.

It's easy to see that despite a "non-theme" theme, this is a fun an enduring game, and it gets a lot of love on BGG.

I just wish I could get it to the table more often...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Ra! Ra! Ra!

Draw a tile or start an auction.  That's it.

And with those two seemingly easy choices you enter a very tightly contested game to see whose Dynasty survives the test of time.

Brilliant design, enjoyable by gamers and new gamers alike.

Even if you tend to shy away from auction games, this one might be your eternal exception.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
(02/28/2009) A wonderful, bidding game, with a "push your luck" element. Very simple turn with few options: 1) pull a tile out the bad, or 2) call 'Ra!', or 3) play a god tile, if you have one. If Ra is called, there is a bidding round to determine who gets the tiles in the center, which is then added to other tiles in their collection to build up fame/legacy points, over three epoch periods. However, there are only so many bids one can make, before being locked-out of the auction for a particular epoch, so players must choose wisely when to 'Ra!'. Fun, thoughtful, game that plays in 45-60 minutes with up to 5 players.

Update (07/16/09): Upping this to a '9' from '8'. It definitely holds up with time, compared to other games.

Update (10/30/11): The original Uberplay version was so much nicer than the reprint. The tiles and fame tokens were much larger. The wooden sun tiles were a bright yellow, instead of this sickly orange color of the reprint. The tiles themselves had an "x" mark to indicate if they were removed at the end of an epoch. Still, the game itself is good. I'm just ranting about the quality of the reprint.

Update (08/25/13): After awhile, this game is no longer a "9", so dropping it to "8". Game hasn't seen much play lately.

Update (01/10/14) 10 plays: Not bad for a pseudo-gateway game. While it is totally luck of the draw, there is some element of skill required to do well. Still, the chaotic nature is starting to bug me. Dropping to a "7".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
thrifted
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Man, I liked this.  Nobody else did.  And the solitaire version requires serious hypnosis, or something.

UPDATE:  Miraculously, this made it to the table again, years (!) later...  and everyone agreed that it deserves deeper exploration.  Looks like it's getting moved into the regular rotation!  Huzzah!

UP-UPDATE:  Damn, this is a great game.  The constant shift in values (with both the lot up for bid being worth different amounts to each player and the power/value of your suns (money) fluctuating as play progresses) makes for a pretty intense game of bluff, brinksmanship, and double-guessing...  It's maddening to have to think about taking a lot that you have absolutely no interest in purely to keep it out of the hands of someone who will score big off of it; it's equally sphincter-clenching to find out that you've worked yourself into a corner where someone else's 1 sun is more powerful than your big, fat 13.  Invoking Ra purely to goad someone into overpaying (just a tad) for something you don't want anyway is sweaty fun.  I could go on and on.  There are depths to this game that aren't even hinted at in the rulebook.  Far, far more than the sum of it's parts.  Deliciously subtle.

Three players may be the sweet spot, as our initial game with five seemed slippery and thin in the control department.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Ra is a brilliant game.  There is so much to like about this game - the fact that the sun tile which wins an auction becomes part of the next items being auctioned; the fact that the sun tiles you win during the first and second epochs will be your bidding ammunition during the next epochs; the push your luck aspect at the end of epochs; the poison pot dilema with catstrophe tiles; the different scoring of tiles, some across epochs, some at the end of the game; the fact that some tiles are discarded after each epoch and others stay throughout the game; the randomness of the Ra tiles, making some epochs end quickly and others run longer.  I love auction games and this is the best in my book.  I will play this game any time.  I've played hundreds of games of the excellent computer version as well.  This game plays very well with the 2-player variant.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
tldr: Simple auction game to teach/learn. You have 3 numbered tokens that you spend when you win a bid, so you may win up to 3 bids per round, one time around auction-style. The simplest advice newbie is to be sure you are gaining points each round (because it is easy to get negative points!)

An auction game that plays over three rounds. Players take turns drawing tiles from a bag until someone calls an auction (by saying "Ra!") or by drawing a Ra tile. Bid is one time around, using the three numbered tokens you have to place a bid. Winning the bid gives you the tiles up for auction (some which may "corrupt" tiles in your collection) and the previous money token used in the last auction. This money token will be available for use in the next round. 
A round ends either when all players have won three auctions (so they have used all three money tokens) or when a certain amount of Ra tokens have been drawn from the bag.

There is a set collection element going on here. Many ways to score negative points if you do not obtain particular types of tiles or if you have the least of a certain type. Should fall in the 45 minute range. Ra!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Ra is a good versatile auction game with a good balance of randomness and long-term strategy (and basically long-term betting, as you don't know how much the different types of tiles could tilt the balance in your favor).

I enjoy it myself, but the problem with it is that it's a little too abstract, so it can be a little difficult to teach to non-gamers (i.e. too many almost-arbitrary tiles that have to be memorized).

RATING: 8
First played this on April 10th, 2007.  This game is fun, doesn't take too long to learn or play based on all the components of it.  We played with 5 people and it played pretty well.  There seems to be a lot of different strategies to take on and there is it's share of luck.  It took a game play to figure out what strategies to try.  I'd recommend giving this one a try.  Don't be discouraged if you don't feel like you know what you are doing, it should come to you after a game play or two.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Easy to teach and easy to learn, but players should never underestimate the tough decisions Ra forces them to make.  With nearly all information public and only three possible decisions on your turn the game is all about making good value judgments - What are the tiles worth to me?; What are the tiles worth to my opponents?; and how can get the tiles for the cheapest amount possible (or get my opponents to pay the most for tile)?

RATING: 8
Ra is a simple set collection game using auctions.  The mechanics are very stripped down but the game still remains surprisingly fun. RATING: 5
An auction game that somehow manages to rob the tension from auctions. It reduces what is normally an extremely tense and interesting game mechanic into a quick series of once around exchanges.

The strategy of when to bid and when to hold out for the end of the round is marginally interesting, but I find the sun mechanic frustrating instead of nerve-wracking.

RATING: 8

RATING: 8
Another round-limited game, but it works well here.  Lots of randomness make for a good number of replays and interesting tension as players bid on tiles.  Should I outbid here with my 15 or wait for something better?  Plays fast, too, which adds to its "just one more game"ness.

My set came with an extra pyramid, but a friend's had the exact number of necessary tiles.  Be sure to count out the tiles before playing!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
One of the best auction games I have played, this is definitely an above average game.  If I were someone who really enjoyed auctions this would be a "9".  I don't really care for them, but this game plays so well that it gets this relatively high rating from me anyway. This rates a half-point higher than its sibling Razzia because of the considerably nicer components and the addition of the devastation tiles which add a higher element of risk to "waiting just one more tile" before you call Ra.  However, the theme itself doesn't seem to work as well with the mechanics as the Razzia theme.  A game with Razzia's theme, Ra's component quality, and an equivalent of the disaster tiles would rate another half-point higher in my book.

RATING: 9
Warning - DO NOT judge this game on the BSW or computer version, it plays/feels COMPLETELY different in person! 

Knizia plus tiles = MAGIC. That really sums it up and every game I've played of his actually. We already played 3 games in 24 hours and its a new fav and very big on fun. For a simple auction and set collection game there is quite a bit of tension and strategy, some with timing and some with scoring making for some tough decisions throughout. Plays excellent with 2, even better with 3 and haven't tried more yet. The scoring in this is no where near as confusing as T&E, not confusing at all for me anyway just after reading the rules. This plays quickly and the game length is short as well making it quite accessible. RA stands for Radical Auctions or Remarkable Auction game! 

[u]UPDATE:[/u] ok 6 plays in 3 days, the rating has edged up and could more. The push your luck element in this is awesome and the game is addicting, like a "good potato chip", hard to play just once. 

[u]UPDATE:[/u] 11 or so plays now and 1 with 4 players which was also good, my initial love affair has died down now but this remains another beaut from Reiner, best middle weight I've played and probably the perfect definition of a 9 for me so rating will stay here I believe

[u]UPDATE:[/u] 9 => 9.25 (probably a 10 though) High replay, scales perfectly from 2 to 5, plays fast with perfect game length of one hour, great gateway game (best I own) that is easy to teach and high high fun factor equals high desire to play, slight rating increase, definite favourite.

[u]UPDATE:[/u] 9.25 => 9 The luck is just too high to rate higher although the effect is somewhat lessened with less players, at least there is a little more control with 2 or 3 which are my favourite numbers to play. RA hit my usual ceiling at around 25 games which is no fault of its own (actually speaks well for it), I use this mostly as a gateway game now and it works very well in this regard.

RATING: 9
It took a bit to get through the rules at first, and I was initially scared that the scoring would be too complicated.  As soon as we started playing the first time though, everything seemed to "click" just right.

This game plays so fluidly yet seems to have so much depth.

The set up time for this is extremely minimal and play is probably around 45 minutes or less.  Because of this, the game is starting to become *the* board game we play when time is limited and we want something a little heavier than most of the card games we have.

Really looking forward to playing this more.

RATING: 6
I'm not a big fan of auction games but not bad as far as they go.  You periodically bid on a set of tiles and try to accumulate sets that will give you lots of points, but every time you bid, the bid you used becomes part of the next lot for someone else to snag.  I never mind playing but I never find myself yearning to play it either.  There's not much in the way of creative strategies or in out thinking opponents and the theme is nearly non-existent, despite an Egyptian motif.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I usually love a good auction game, but the mechanic that makes me dislike Ra is that one is very constrained with what can be bid. It's probably a great mechanic for those who hate long, drawn-out auctions in games, but I miss it tremendously here.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Nice auction game, but it'll take a few plays to get it's teeth into you. 

This always seems to be a popular choice with my group now, although I can't help thinking that I prefer some of Knizia's other auctioners a little more. The limited, publicly visible remaining bids in each players hand means it comes down to making very predictable plays sometimes. This is good, though, as it cuts straight to the psychological battle of trying to force other players into wasting their bids on inferior auction groups. Feels a little less fun and more basic than Traumfabrik or Palazzo, but there's no denying the elegance of Knizia's design here.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
2012-05-03

Initial Rating: 7.0 (May 2012)

After 1 play I can say I liked the game. I still think Modern Art is better but Ra is a fine game. I love auction games and Ra is one of the best auction games out there. As it is common with a Knizia game, the theme is very thin but the gameplay is very good and tense.

You have to make very hard decisions in a very short time frame. The multiple ways scoring system is very well done allowing for a lot of complex plays.

The game is simple enough to teach in 5 minutes but deep enough to appeal to the inner gamer in me :D.

I suspect with more plays the rating will go up.

Current Rating: 7.0
[hr]
2014-07-21

With more plays I continue to like Ra, in fact I bought the game and I plan to keep it in my collection. Still I prefer to play Modern Art so Ra won’t hit the table as often. I’m downgrading its rating so it matched my feelings with the BGG recommended rating system. 

Still a good Knizia game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Looks (and is) hugely abstract, this has as much to do with ancient Egypt as it does with mowing my lawn ... but it is one of the most fun auction games out there. 

While at first the scoring rules look very obtuse and make the game look more complicated than it really is, on each turn usually you only have a choice of one of two things to do (call 'Ra!' or draw a tile). But as with all of Dr. Knizia's best games, behind the simple rules lies a subtle and constantly changing game. 

You can only win a maximum of three sets of tiles in each of the three rounds, so balancing the best point scoring opportunities for yourself against baulking others makes for some deliciously agonising decisions.

Deservedly a Euro-classic, and for me on a shortlist of two for the definitive auction game (alongside Dr. K's Modern Art).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Dutch, 999 Games & Uberplay editions (w/player aid mats).   This is a quick and easy to learn family-friendly game with a surprising amount of substance to it.  RA is a game of tactical bidding and set-collecting that requires the ability to maximize limited opportunities while supporting a variety of ways to score.  I like the intense excitement felt by the contrast in luck and control in drawing and bidding for tiles while attempting to collect and/or manipulate various valued tiles to and from your opponents.  Best when played with 3.

iTouch/iPad =D

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A true classic. As with Knizia's other masterpiece, Tigris and Euphrates, every element fits perfectly together. Although this is a pure auction game with only three or four auction values per epoch, there is still a ton of *subtle* strategic variety in when and what to shoot for. The aspect that I think makes this game special is that the last bid is included in the next auction, thus with each auction you are setting yourself up - good or bad - for future auctions. The game is perfect for what it is. Deceptively simple.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
En primer lugar tengo que decir que odio los juegos de subastas. En serio, no puedo jugar a ellos porque me considero una persona que no sabe ver cuando es el momento adecuado para hacer una oferta y cuando es un buen momento para plantarse.

Afortunadamente, mis problemas con las subastas se solucionan cuando juego a este juego. En Ra no tienes una gran variedad de opciones para hacer una puja, sino que sólo tienes tres números por ronda. Eso hace el juego mucho más fácil para un jugador como yo, ya que limita las opciones sólo a tres.

Éste es un clásico juego de "colección de sets" con la mecánica de subastas antes mencionada.
[color=green]
LAST PLAY: 2010
[/color][color=blue]
First of all I have to say that I hate auction games. Seriously, I can't play them because I consider myself a person who can't see when it is the right moment to bid and when it's the good one to stop.

Fortunately, my problems with bidding are solved when I play this game. In Ra you don't a huge range of options in order to bid but only three numbers per round. That makes the game far easier for a player like me, limiting options just to three.

This game is a classic "set collection" game with the above mentioned bidding mechanics.[/color]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is one of those games that is a good solid game but should not be anywhere near the Top 10, in my opinion.  There is a huge luck factor in having a really good tile pulled out of the bag by the player going in front of you.  Then you can use a God tile or call an auction, either winning it or forcing others to pay alot.  Sure, there is some skill involved in knowing what to do but there's good and bad fortune depending on what side of the "how many sun tiles left in the bag" side of the equation.  I much prefer the more interesting and dynamic game, Traumfabrik, by the same designer, which I feel is thematically and conceptually far superior to this game which is unfortunately much more widely known and available because of the publisher and its earlier publication date.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I came to Ra as a staunch skeptic of Knizia. At first glance you have a very simple auction game in which tiles are drawn from a bag and occasionally an auction for lots of those tiles is initiated. The game's 'bounce-rate' comes from the scoring complexity of the tiles: some are required to avoid penalties, some are worth more in the right combinations, some are short-term, some long-term, etc. etc. Valuation isn't exactly intuitive, and it's hard to learn it quickly because players only get one crack at each auction, and don't have an incremental currency. Indeed, the game features a kind of backwards-approach where you're trying to best apply chunky, discrete-value bids to constantly changing tile-sets. Every other auction game does it the other way around. 

Once you get over the initial hurdle, Ra is a classic. The system is incredibly fluid and resilient - it keeps players on their toes re-evaluating tiles, position, long-term potential, etc. High Suns and low suns both have their uses. Timing is huge, and close attention must be paid to everyone's relative position and incentives. Players who understand what's going on here should be engaged every step of the way. A turn is Ra is simple - draw or call - but the dynamics of the game are not. 

A lot has been said about the poor integration of theme in this game, but I think that's overblown. This game does 3000 years in 45 minutes, so of course there's no answer to the "who am I as a decision-maker?" question. The Suns vaguely represent an entire civilization's good will with Ra, in exchange for which boons in agriculture, architecture, etc. are received. The tiles do a decent job characterizing the ebb and flow of a civilization, with one year of history scaling to one second of game time. One auction in Ra represents the fortunes of 2-5 generations. It's not really a "problem" of gaffes or contradictions, it's a matter of detail. Look elsewhere if you want more of it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.6
What. A. Beautiful. Game. I'd play this any day at any time with any body.  Period.  The more I get into Knizia's games the more I come to respect him.  The game is based on a fixed amount of "Money" (for lack of a better description) which can be used each epoch for bidding.  This money has absolutely no value other than being able to beat your neighbours amounts.  I just think it's so simple yet so complex.  As close to perfect as you can get.  The "Luck" factor even works VERY well with it.  there's the luck of the tile draw, but you can usually weigh the odds against what you've already seen come out.  In a 5 player game, it eventually comes down to a 50/50 draw for the last 2 tiles.  Beautiful!!  All of that, AND you get to say "RA" quite frequently.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Ra may be my favourite from the Alea big box series though I haven't played it enough yet to decide. This is due to my bias that I generally prefer more tactical games and evaluating values in auctions as a mean to succeed in contrast to learning generic strategies as in Puerto Rico or Princes of Florence.
Ra is one of the top auction games as it is quick and comparably accessible. The idea of a limited amount of bids with fixed values available to each player is brilliant. Combined with the push-your-luck element from the random tile draw replay and fun value is huge if you enjoy auction games.

RATING: 8.3
維勵買的~~
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Phenomenal auction game; the best of its class in my opinion. The scoring can seem overcomplicated to a neophyte, but it's this diversity in situational value that makes each tile draw very interesting. The value of a given set of tiles can fluctuate at a moment's notice and can mean different things to different players. That would be too chaotic EXCEPT that you can see exactly what everyone's bidding power is at any time. The key to success is to call auctions and manipulate players with strong bidding power to pay for mediocre lots, else you get it very cheap with your low power. There is nothing more satisfying than watching the high power tiles go unplayed as Ra closes off the board. Nothing more frustrating than watching a hesitant bidder freely grab 8 or even 16(!) free tiles at the end of an epoch. A lot of tactical strategy and enough luck and push-your-luck to keep everyone on their toes. Awesome. Awesome. One more time. Awesome!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Oh, Ra, why dost thou hate me?

A fun, lighthearted auction game that's amusingly themed and relatively easy on newcomers owing to the fact that the auctions are restrained and the options limited by the sun bidding tokens. Not as deep or as rich as Modern Art but also not as intimidating. There seem to be multiple paths to victory, though that is only based on my observations of others, not on personal experience. A monument strategic adopted early on seems particularly effective if the tile draws allow it. The trickiest bit for me is knowing what to do with the mid-value sun tokens (not expecting too much but not going out too early).

RATING: 9
Even after reading the rules, I was completely bewildered by this game on my first play.  The second game has made it a little more clear.  It's not that the rules were complicated, but more that the bidding system of this auction-based game is so different than any other (even all the other Knizias I've played).  Knowing how to value the tiles, when to bid, when to pass and when to invoke Ra is a challenge.  I look forward to playing this more, and I suspect that my rating will go up with increased play.

Update: After 6 plays, it's beginning to click.  I'm raising my rating to an 8.  Further update: Who am I kidding, this needs to go up to a 9!  :)

RATING: 8
Simple game of bidding and balancing how much the ante is worth. [b]Good mechanic, but actions feel forced at times.[/b] The person controlling the highest number has great control over the game. Overall, its ideal to have an average of high numbers (like [gameid=172]), but it's a balance of taking low numbers to get the tiles you want (kinda like [gameid=9027]).

It's [b]simple and fast. A recommended bidding mathy game[/b]. The mechanics and scoring are alluring enough to keep the game in the back of my mind.

RATING: 8
What a wonderful surprise. Reading the rules might lead you to believe this is a brute force auction game collecting sets and lording it over your opponents. I.e. essentially quite dull. That would be the case if you hadn't noticed this was by Reiner Knizia (or didn't know who he was). When playing the game all sorts of considerations and push-your-luck style strategies must be employed. The theme fits quite nicely in this case and makes for a beautiful game. I wanted to play again immediately and expect this will be a regular on my various gaming tables.
If space is an issue I'd strongly recommend Razzia! It's a remake by Knizia but with cards.

RATING: 8.5
There's a cool tile payout system, and a nice push your luck aspect, but the Sun tiles really make this game: they limit your decision space, increasing the pace; they make money management more interesting without making it convoluted; plus, they add to the interactions in how you can push your opponents: bidding 6 when your opponent has 2-5-13 forces their hand, without costing you much. Great stuff.

RATING: 6
Auction game where you bid for sets with forty million scoring types and simultaneously for future bidding power. So far I like it a little less than Modern Art, which in spite of the randomly dealt cards is driven by player initiative; here everything in uncertain and sometimes you can/must trust in pure luck to hand you the points you need. The set collection seems overwrought considering there are considerably more elegant ways of achieving asymmetric valuation (as seen in for instance No Thanks!), but the bidding instruments are more manageable than the victory points of Modern Art.

RATING: 10
My favorite auction game.  Beautiful and deep.  I never tire of Ra.  Through about 100 games, I was still learning, still encountering new situations, learning to control the options the other players have.  I understand that some learners find the laundry list of ways to score untidy.

Every bit as good with 2 players as with 3 or 4.  (Rules with 2:  Start one player with the {2,5,7,8} suns, and the other with the {3,4,6,9} suns.  Put the first Ra tile TWO spaces to the right of the space marked "3 players".)

RATING: 9
This game is so simple yet it is one of the deepest game there is. Most of the game you either draw a tile or start an auction but the times you start the auction can mean win or loss for you. It is so tense when people look at each other and someone calls an auction and everyone just gasps. I love the tension of the game. It takes a couple of plays to get a hang of the game but when people get it then it is so much fun. I like For Sale for its simplicity but if we are playing a serious auction game Ra is the one we play. I also love the new artwork but the price is a bit high for what you get.

2018-01-14 - This game is excellent with 3 and 4 players. With 5 it gets a little crowded, but it's still good. However with 5 I would choose Modern Art or Traumfabrik over this one. I'm still yet to try it with 2.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Great auction game. I really like the way the values of different tiles is really dependent on what else is out there. Maybe for that reason, I find this to be an easier auction game for first-timers to compete in than most -- where you really need to have a feel for values to do well. I think that's because the auctioning is done using tiles, so even a novice know their maximum value. This game remains fresh play after play. And I think it just plain looks great.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Good game!  The theme, or motiff, is plausable.  As a pure auction game, Ra is all about leveraging your resources, and seeing what a lot is worth both to yourself, but to the other bidders.  The movement of the bidding tokens is innovative.  Knowing when you should prompt an auction, or add to alot is a key point, and this decision is tied to which bidding tile you hope to win with, what other bidding tokens you might have to compete against, and which bidding token you will get with the lot of goods.  Add in the disasters, the ticking clock of the Ra track, and you get a tense event that demands that the players take chances and cope with the luck of the draw.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

app

RATING: 8
Acquired soon after Puerto Rico, this has grown into one of my favourites. Wonderful art, and I think the theme fits very well with the mechanics. A worthy addition is the player air boards which provide both a handy overview of the tiles, a scoring summary and a consistent placeholder for the tiles over all players, providing easy overview of other players aquisitions. (I've provided a pdf of the original .jpg player aid for the Alea Ra version in the files section. It makes for easier printing with the correct dimensions.)

Bought this for EUR16 in a sale at Tradition in Uppsala, given that I'd read about it on the geek. Didn't know about it being OOP and sought after, so more power to me, I suppose. Also my first German edition game, I think.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
A great game with very unique mechanics.  The main point of the game is to collect sets of different tiles over two epochs, and this is done by repeated "once-around" auctions.  In reality, however, this game boils down to pushing your luck and finding a balance about when to initiate auctions and how long to wait before you bid on them.  One of my top 10 favorite games of all time.  

For more information, check out my review
at
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/1351
693#1351693

RATING: 9
[b]Purchase/Selling History[/b]: 
My first TANGA purchase '06.

[b]Rating: 9.0[/b]
[i]Design rating:[/i] [b]5[/b] 
[i]Component rating:[/i] [b]1[/b] 
[i]Willingness to play rating:[/i] [b]1.5[/b] 
[i]Fun rating:[/i] [b]1.5[/b] 

[b]Players considerations[/b]: 
More the better, but even works with 2 in variant, seems short but the accumulation of tiles is fair and accurate to other size games.

[b]My thoughts[/b]: 
This is probably a perfect game, yeah there is some luck, but you have to use even the luck to your advantage in this game to win. Nice tiles and "suns". I'm actually pretty good at this game. More experienced players rarely let the board get too full of tiles before invoking Ra, so that takes a bit of the fun away because it is all about calling auction when your opponents possess higher tiles; then you can go in for your own auctions. It is a great balancing mechanism though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Ra is the perfect example of how to design an auction game: all the mechanisms work perfectly, and it has a really engaging "push your luck" element. Indeed, the game has only one flaw: the theme, which is nonexistent. 

I don't mind abstracts, but I would have preferred to bid for something more plausible than a God, a pyramid and bunch of gold coins: the theme is so thin it gets in the way, as scoring isn't straightforward at all. To make matters worse, it's utterly impossible to follow anything resembling a plan without truly understanding and internalizing the scoring mechanism.

Due to that, it can give a horrible first impression: someone will win, and few players, if any, will understand why. Still, it's worth a second try, because it's terribly fun and engaging. Every time your turn takes place a lot of interesting possibilities will emerge, so you'll have to decide what to do by studying the possible outcomes, while simultaneously deciding if you should push your luck a bit more.

The game plays extremely well both with three and four players and the experience is quite different with both: with three you'll have more things under control, while with four both luck and the agonizing decisions increase. With five chaos reigns supreme and can easily get frustrating.

Rating: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
Optimal number of players:
:thumbsup:3
:thumbsdown:5

RATING: 9
I hate all auction games...except Ra.

Every mechanism in this game is a part of a greater whole. The decision to launch an auction prematurely, the open auction mechanism, etc...Everything is important to make this a great calculation (with a touch of bluff) game.

Of course, being a Knizia game, the theme is useless and for this game it actually hinders the rules comprehension. The first thing I say to new players is "There is a theme, Ancien Egypt, now forget about it we play an abstract game". This one thing makes the game less attractive, and knock it from 10 to 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Auction game, with an Egyptian theme. (been reprinted)

Ra is an auction and set-collection game with an Ancient Egyptian theme. Each turn players are able to purchase lots of tiles with their bidding tiles (suns). Once a player has used up his or her suns, the other players continue until they do likewise, which may set up a situation with a single uncontested player bidding on tiles before the end of the round occurs. Tension builds because the round may end before all players have had a chance to win their three lots for the epoch. The various tiles either give immediate points, prevent negative points for not having certain types at the end of the round (epoch), or give points after the final round. The game lasts for three "epochs" (rounds). The game offers a short learning curve, and experienced players find it both fast-moving and a quick play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I really, really like this game.  You can teach it quickly and it plays fast, and I love the strategy.  It takes a few plays for people to catch on to what is sound strategy and what isn't, but that's okay because it plays fast.

RATING: 8.6
I would have never thought before that a medium-heavy game with such a relatively high luck factor can work. Push-your-luck mechanism in a very thinking game? How could it work? Knizia is ingenious.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[2007.Oct.5] Ra is not just another auction game. The prolific game designer Reiner Knizia created a masterpiece with this one. In typical Knizia style, the game is simple to learn, but hard to master. The subtleties of starting an auction (by calling out "Ra!" during your turn) is what the entire game revolves around. The ancient Egyptian theme is a good fit for this game, although it could easily be ported to another theme. The game is played in three epochs with a scoring phase after each epoch ends. After first 2 epochs, some tiles are discarded while others remain; the 3rd epoch, culminates with each player scoring the monuments that their empire has built over the course of the 3 epochs. In my experience, the game scales well, whether it is played with only 3 players, with 4, or with all 5 players. The Überplay version of this game is well crafted, and should be present in every gamer's collection. May the Egyptian gods smile upon your empire... but beware their disastrous wrath, for they can be quite fickle.

RATING: 5
Took several plays to "get" it. Interesting auction mechanism, different numbers for bidding are distributed to players. Different titles score differently (set collection). Player with the most of a certain title scores positive points, player with least titles of a type looses points. Feels like the game plays the player vs. the other way around. It is clearly not for everyone. Just can't get into this game even when I treat it as a trick taking card game with bidding. There are other Reiner Knizia games I like better: Samurai, Poison, and Tigris & Euphrates to name a few. This leaves me flat.

RATING: 6
I'm a fan.  Played a dozen or two games on BSW.  It's RK's cleverest auction game, in the way that you have to balance your priorities and the wonderful sun-tile economy.

That said, the game is a bit too number-crunchy and mechanical for me.  There's none of the incentive manipulation and alliance-brokering in of Modern Art, nor the simplicity and theme-richness of Traumfabrik, both of which I own. 

Too, I suspect dealing with so many tiles would get tedious when done in real life instead of on the internet.  In sum, I like the game but feel no tug to buy a physical copy.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My wife and I never had any auction games, mostly since they tend not to work with just two players. However, we heard so many good things about [thing=12][/thing] that we finally decided to get a copy (plus, we reasoned, it would always be good to have in case friends came over). 

I convinced her to give it a try and she was skeptical---the rules sounded so simple, how could it be fun? But it was! And it worked great with just the two of us! The constrained auction works brilliantly with two. You really have to weigh in how much the set is worth to you and how much it's worth to your opponent, as well as how much the remaining auctions may be worth. There is also a bit of psychology to guessing when your opponent will bid or not. Arguably, the two player version is more tense and tight than with more since there's more control and less time for chaos between your turns. We did have some friends over and played several 4-player games which were good but different, with a little more "push your luck" now since it takes more time between turns. Still, a fun game and worthy of all its accolades (but you do need to print one of the excellent player mats found here).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
A very clever game though you have to play it many, many times until you start understanding all its nuances. The initial impression is that the luck factor is very huge and almost game breaking - only later will you realize that by playing wisely you can reduce the random element to a minimum. Like most Knizia games Ra has many scoring opportunities and you have to concentrate on only a few to be really successful, though you could try to spread thin and gamble a bit.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ra is a brilliant bidding game with set bids. Instead of specific currency, players are given tokens with numbers which are then traded for another token with a lower or higher number together with its goods. This creates a rather unique bidding experience in which each player has to value not only the goods but also the numbered token that comes with it especially when said numbered token will then be used to bid again in the next round. A truly impressive game but as usual with most Reiner Knizia's games the scoring can be a little difficult to get used to but a very important aspect of the game as you need to know how to score in order to know how to value the tiles correctly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
A nice auction game, in which you try to time auctions to give you the best bargains, and make other players spend high for what they need.  On the down side, the scoring rules are hard to remember.  And I don’t like the end of round play, which amounts to betting against drawing a RA tile.

RATING: N/A
Players: 2-5
Best: 3-4
Time: 45-60 Min
Type: Strategy 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A few observations

* This game is incredibly simple and straightforward. The core rules systems take less than two minutes to explain, and the scoring takes, perhaps, another minute and a half. I can't explain Carcassonne or other "family" boardgames that quickly.

* The box and included draw bag for the Uberplay edition that I own need to be about 10% larger, or the tiles need to be marginally smaller. It is extremely difficult to mix the tiles up in the bag at the start of the game, and it is awkward storing the tiles in the bag inside the box, since they tend to prop up the board and, in turn, the top of the box.

* I have heard reports of the draw bag splitting along its bottom seam, but mine seems sturdy so far. My board has warped slightly, though, possibly due to the open design of the cardboard box insert or being propped up on top of the tiles. Publisher's take note - I am perfectly happy to pay another dollar or so for a well-designed, blown plastic insert that supports the gameboard well.

* While deciding whether to reprint Ra, Uberplay considered changing the theme to the free agent market in professional (American) football. This would have been a gigantic mistake. Although I am a sports fan, a lot of game geeks are not, and would have been actively turned off by the new theme. The Ancient Egypt theme is more abstract, and less likely to actively grab anyone's attention, but it is even less likely to turn anyone off in the way a sports theme would. I doubt a change in theme would draw in enough new, non-gamer, buyers to offset the number of gamers that would be turned off by it.

* Ra is underrated as a gateway game. Like I said above, the rules are extremely straightforward and easy to grasp. In addition, the graphics are eye-catching and the screwage is just about perfect - sufficient to avoid any feeling of multiplayer solitaire, but indirect enough to avoid bad feelings.

So All Hail Mighty Ra!, king of the middleweight auction games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A cursory look at this game might make you think this is a light luck-dominated game, but make no mistake this is an excellent auction game.  Balancing all the different scoring methods, avoiding losing points here and trying to gain points here, makes a wonderfully tight game, where you have to agonize over whether you are getting enough for you biggest bid.  Many things to consider but only so much you can do to affect your position, the amount of strategic depth is limited (though there is some), you are often just looking to make the best of what you get and hope that is enough.  The luck of the draw does come into it, as is to be expected in a game where tiles are pulled out randomly, and no player can expect to win every time, but a good player will generally do well.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The game seems to emphasize dabbling in a lot of scoring categories rather than focusing on one or two. The bidding premise is good, though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
"Ra" is a simple game.  That being said, there is some awesome fun in this box.  It is full of press-your-luck auctions, dynamic bidding positions, and the "epoch" is steadily but surely running down as sand in an hourglass.  Experienced players have a nose for when to invoke "Ra", based on an opponents bidding ability, and the relative value of the "pot".  This causes interesting interaction, putting stress on an opponent with perhaps stronger bidding power but fewer remaining bids.  There is definitely a gambling factor, and randomness of the draw pile, so not to be taken too seriously.  But this game can be hilarious.  Skilled players will win consistently over newer players.

The beauty of this game comes from the simple mechanics, which never the less lead to excruciating decisions for each player.  Newbies who lose their bidding power right away may suffer unfortunate down-time as they wait to join in again at the next epoch.  

Along with Tigris & Euphrates, Ra is among Knizia's best board games.  Also one of the best iOS apps out there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
What a strange game.  Curiously dry, willfully random, but a deep strategic exercise.  Would need more experience with it to truly fix on what it is.  It's not that it's fun, but I can see how it might be fun, though that vision feels like it's glimpsed through a thick fog and several refracting mirrors.  My guess is that becoming good at it develops a kind of zen intuition as far as how and where to play your oh-so-limited bids.  Not my game, I don't think, but fascinating in its way.

11/2007 Rating up a ontch :) This is still an exciting game after all these years.  There's a lot more going on there than in Medici; although the latter is purer.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
One of the best bidding games I have played. The typical Knizia scoring system makes it possible to have a few basic strategies but in large it is tactical decissions in relation to what bidding tiles you hold that decides the outcome of the game. 

It plays quickly with low downtime,even with 5 players, since the number of actions to take each turn is very low and fast. 

Scales well between 3 and five players but requires different tactics and strategies dependent of the number of players. 

Very high player interaction level and lots of fun and great replayabillity. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
(Col·lecció MJ)

RATING: 9
Very approachable game as easy to teach, but plenty of subtlety for more advanced gamers.  I have never met anyone who does not say "Hey!  Let's play that again."  The quick time to play and multiple scoring paths are a blast when combined with the short game time (failed risks do not damage you for too long --> 1 game down, let's play again v. 4 hours of finishing a losing position in some other game).

One quibble...the ultimate hosing of drawing a RA tile just after a RA bid...now you may lose a good sun for a crappy sun and maybe even have your turn end.  There is simply nothing you can do about it and you may take a ton of negative points if you have not protected yourself with pharoahs and civilization tiles.  (Guess how my last game went!)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Ra is an auction and set-collection game with an Ancient Egyptian theme. Each turn players are able to purchase lots of tiles with their bidding tiles. Once a player has used up his or her Suns, the other players continue until they do likewise, which may set up a situation with a single uncontested player bidding on tiles before the end of the round occurs. Tension builds because the round may end before all players have had a chance to win their three lots for the epoch. The tiles give either immediate points, prevent negative points for not having certain types at the end of the round (epoch), or give points after the final round. The game lasts for three "epochs" (rounds). The game offers a short learning curve, and experienced players find it both fast-moving and a quick play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I don't normally enjoy pure bidding games.  However, I think I enjoy this one because everybody starts with only 3 bidding tiles.  There is a lot of open information that allows you to quickly evaluate what the current lot may be worth to your opponents.  Add on the fact that you also know which sun tiles they have available compared to you and you can really put them in some tough positions.  One of the best things about the game is how simple your actual options are on your turn - either call Ra or draw a tile.  Instead of being bogged down by rules or game options, you spend your time analyzing the current game state.  Very elegant!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
(Played only with 5 players)

A unique auction game with weird mechanics, including push-your-luck element. Works greatly.

Every player has three (and only three) opportunities to buy tiles, regardless of value of their sun tokens. Plus, it is hard to know value of tiles exactly. Furthermore, no one knows whetther the value of tiles would go up or down. Consequently, you can get good tiles even if you have only sun tokens with lower numbers, if you bid with proper timing.

Generally I don't like convoluted scoring much, but it works great here. Convoluted scoring makes estimation of value of tiles harder, and game play more unpredictable.

Unique auction system and complicated scoring gives you some control, and makes this game much more fascinating and intriguing than other simpler auctions games and other simpler push-your-luck games.

UPDATE----------------------------------
Played with 3 and 4. My opinion didn't change.

RATING: 1.5
I coincide with that said by Greg Schloesser: turn actions are very limited, boring, repetitive, take the tile in less than 1 second until one player calls for an auction. Stop: think something and again, all the players...take the tile, etc......stop....auction....Very boring.
  
In fact I was the one in charge of taking out the tiles. My hand always in the bag and asking: Tile?, yes, tile?, yes and so on.Sometimes i make the question but before the answer the tile was put in the board, asuming an obvious answer. And i never was wrong in my assumptions. 

  During the same week that we learned Ra we were learning Santiago and Tower of Babel. What a difference! 
  
Very basic, primitive, and simple auction game. Sincerely I don't understand how it is among the TOP 300 of the BGG.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A solid 8.  I really enjoy the bidding system, and it's always interesting to see how the different lots available for bid, the number of "Ra" tiles that have come up, and each player's available suns will interact to affect when an auction gets called and what folks will bid.

Would be higher, but it's just a little dry for some tastes.  And I have had it fall flat in a group a time or two.  But the game plays fast enough that I've never really felt like I didn't get the appropriate payoff for the time invested.

I highly recommend the player aid available here (the  individual player mats that assist in organizing purchased tiles and in visualizing how the scoring works).  They're priceless, and should have been included with the game.

RATING: 5
Likes:
- The components are nice.
- Very clever idea of bidding not only for reward (tiles), but also for the very means of bidding itself (suns).

Dislakes:
- It's kinda boring, despite good mechanics.
- It's strongly luck-dependent.
- You do very little in your turn while at the same time you really don't need to negotiate with others (like e.g. in Modern Art). So you end up feeling little involved in the game.

RATING: 7.35
"Wait, this is a game?" That was my thought after watching a video review of it. After playing it, I would like to say, "Yes Virginia, there is a game in there." Oh, there's absolutely no theme outside of similar images being used on the game pieces. Has other pet peeve things like getting points for having three of a certain item. Somehow a flood is a good thing, but too many floods doesn't do anything negative.

The auction aspect is its saving grace. It took about midway through the game before my brain even began to process correctly what was going on. After that the beauty of the game took over. I wanted to hate this game, and if I had continued on my path, I would have. It had somehow worked its way into my brain and made me think about it even the next day. It might be a one trick pony, but it's one hell of a pony. I fear more plays will only make my rating go up.

Played at DaveCon 2012.

Rating Potential: 7.5-8.5. I think moving up is asking a lot though. If there was any sort of theme implemented properly in this game, it would go to a 9.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Initially Ra didn't do much for me.  

For me, the enjoyment of this game depends more on the enjoyment of my opponents.  That's of course true in a lot of games but it seems to matter more in Ra.

It's a fast moving game and you do feel involved in the flow since your turn lasts such a short amount of time. If your opponents don't go into brain lock as to whether to call Ra or pull a tile, then you'll have fun. Otherwise... yuck.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[i]Ra[/i] is my favorite game of the 60+ I have played thus far.  It combines two of my favorite mechanics, bidding and set collection, in a unique way that involves a lot of player interaction.  The game is short (45-60 minutes) and easy to learn, and has a nice skill/luck blend that makes it quite re-playable.

Just as in poker, your options each turn are few, yet it is difficult to determine which is optimal.  Knowing whether to call Ra, draw a tile, or play a God tile requires an understanding not only of the probabilities involved, but also the psychology of your opponents (a trait found in many of Knizia's games).  It really is a combination of math/art, and playing frequently with the same group enhances one's enjoyment of the game.

[i]Ra[/i] is enjoyable with 3-5 players (I have yet to play with two).  Most will find it best with 3 or 4.  I rate the game a 9.5-10 with 3 players and a 9-9.5 with 4-5 players.  I wouldn't be surprised if my rating changes to a 10 at some point, but I would prefer to play more games first.

Edit - I have now played [i]Ra[/i] with two players and I rate it a 9.  It is still a great game, but I believe the luck factor might be a bit higher than in a 3-4 player game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Between 01/31/06 and 03/02/16 I've played 23 times; fairly evenly divided between 3, 4, and 5-player games. I'm glad we played the first time (using the original version) with a display cheat sheet. Otherwise I'd have been lost. A pleasant game that scales well from 3 to 5 players. 
The mechanics work very well. I enjoy the game's Egyptian atmosphere. Yet the theme is obviously pasted on, as some of it has no basis in reality. Examples: What are "suns"? What are Ra tiles? What are the pharaoh tiles? They can't be the actual pharaoh, as there are oodles of them. Who/what do the players represent? So, just play the game and don't think too much about the theme or it'll drive you crazy.

RATING: 8
It's a reasonable game, of which I'd tire if I played it too often. I'd give it a 7, but the novelty and beauty of it merit a bump to 8. There are aspects of Ra that I really like, and others that mildly annoy me. One notable positive is the "sun tile" auction, because there is more to consider than "zero balance/expectation" in decision making. The "chicken" aspect is also quite interesting. 

There should be some check on the player's ability to call an auction at any time. In some games, people "Ra" too frequently and it becomes disruptive.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Game in a Nutshell: Lightly-themed auction game of set collecting where players randomly grab what goes up on the auction block.

Played as: 3,4,5 player

Pros: Streamlines auctions in a way that is simple and fast moving yet retains hard, game-altering choices. Best of all, it doesn't take a half dozen plays to get the game understood so that it runs within its suggested playtime (less then 1 hour) and one that people will be willing/wanting to give a second go back-to-back.

Cons: The theme doesn't cover up the fact it's an interactive math problem. Really all it does is make it a prettier game to play-- that's it. Games can be close enough that a little string of unfortunate luck can feel like a big deal. Seems to be the type of game you forget about if you don't play it for a while.

Other: I've read other people say that this game loses its interest after the first 15 or so plays. I didn't think that would be true for me initially as I saw it shoot into my top 5 games for a while. Then it just sort of happened... it disappeared from the rotation of games getting played and I didn't really care. I still think it's a great game and an example of how to make auctions great without the need for heavy number crunching, but it just lost that edge it had for me.

Best Use: When you want to maximize interesting decisions in a short amount of time with a smaller group.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I think I liked this pretty well, and I wasn't expecting to. Play time is reasonable, the scoring system is fairly easy to grasp and there appear to be a lot of viable strategies.

It's a good combination of easy to get into but difficult to master. The fact that a given lot might be great for you good for someone else and bad for someone else make bidding quite interesting. I really like the swapping out of the sun tiles after an auction win. I like the way that smaller sun tiles are sneaky useful in certain situations. I like that you sometimes find yourself weighing whether to go ahead and buy a lot that has a disaster tile in it. I like that you can try to force another player's hand or dare another player to overpay for something.

I'm not big on Eurogames, but I like this better than most I've tried. I give it a 5 because I'm not likely to ask to play, but I'll probably be willing to play occasionally if asked.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
There are many ways to win in this game, and players are rarely out of it at the beginning. I love the asynchronous scoring opportunities, the way you have to weigh what you are bidding with not only the tiles you will win but with the sun you will get back for next round AND with the value of the lot to other opponents. Just a great game all around! And this is the only auction game I've played where calling for an auction can be an offensive, forcing move to other players. Plus, this game is fun with 2 players.

RATING: 10
This may be my favorite auction game. Rather different from a traditional auction
                                                   game, it borrows aspects from several other games as well as a few novel bits of its
                                                   own. The discrete nature of the bidding tiles, the wide range of scoring options, the
                                                   simple but important strategic decision of when to call an auction and the reasonably
                                                   playing time combine to make this an outstanding game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A Knizia auction game which as per usual has multiple ways to score.  In Ra there are about 15 ways to score with straights, sets, negative points for not collecting certain items, end-of-round and end-game scoring, etc.  The money is tight, and similar to the money in For Sale, where players are given just 4 bidding values to use each round.  The money you bid with is recycled and added to the next auction (although when you win money in an auction you cannot use it 'til the next round).  There's some chance in this one as you're trying collect items that may never come up.  Players must diversify, keep track of what their opponents are collecting & set themselves up for scoring opportunities.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The pieces are nice.  The theme is stamped on it, but I don't really care about that either way here.  It's fun the first few times, but ages quickly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a fun game that I have been wanting for a while now.  Somebody happened to have it at my FLGS on game night so I finally got a chance to try it out.  It made me want it even more.  I'll be buying this game when it comes back in print sometime in August, hopefully it doesn't get pushed back any more.

In Ra players bid for tiles that are being drawn to score the most points.  Okay, so there is this whole Egyptian theme and all, but really you can paste in about any theme you want.  To me it really doesn't have much to do with the game.  The game is played over 3 rounds, sorry epochs.  After each round all tiles you have collected are scored, except for the monuments which only score at the end of the game.  Some of the tiles you keep throughout the epochs, others are thrown out after scoring.

I think what I like most about this game is the auction.  To me it is new and I don't know of another game that does this, although there might be some.  You have 3 Ra pieces with numbers on them.  Those are the values you have to bid during an auction.  So if I have the numbers 3, 7, and 12, those are the only 3 bids I can offer.  The bidding is also a once round bid, so if you are first bidder you have a tough choice to make sometimes.  Also, when you make a bid, there is another Ra piece in the middle of the board, you have to place your bid there, and take the one that is already there.  Those new pieces you take are your bidding options for the next epoch, so that also factors into the decision.

The tiles you are bidding on are drawn randomly from a bag, some are good, some destroy your other tiles.  This is another interesting twist in the game.  There might be some really good stuff up there, but there might be some disasters as well.

I give this game a solid 8.  It is a lot of fun, and although the tiles coming out are pure luck, you still have to plan with your bids as to what you are willing to take.  The auction mechanic alone is very interesting to me.  Of course Knizia has to come up with weird ways to score, luckily, at least in the version we played with, all the needed information is printed plainly around the board.

[b]Game Length:[/b] (Short) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Long)
[b]Complexity:[/b] (Easy) :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: (Complex)
[b]Accessibility:[/b] (Non-Gamers) :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: (Gamers)

[b]Recommended # of Players:[/b] 4

RATING: 9
One of the best designed auction games that I've played and my favourite game from Knizia's Auction Trilogy.  A classic.

I've owned both the Rio Grande/Alea and the Uberplay edition.  Much prefer the Uberplay edition due to the compact box, thicker tiles and the user friendly graphics that act as mnemonics during gameplay, thereby improving the game's accessibility.

Best played with 3 players imo (OK with 4p, and alright with 5p, due to decreased control).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My all time favorite.  Ra simplifies the bidding mechanic by giving players fixed bids.  This rachets up the tension as you must decide whether to take tiles (and lose bids) or risk losing the tiles.  In addition, unlike most bidding games, not everything in play in Ra will be auctioned.  Players must decide when to call auctions, and that decision is the game's most important.  Finally, the complex scoring system allows for many possible winning strategies.  Ra is a masterpiece.
