=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Played once.  This is an auction game where luck (which items are drawn) and tactics (when and how much to bid) both weigh heavily.  Players bid for items using one of three chips (from a set numbered 1-16) they have; the winning bidder gets all the items up for auction, but leaves their chip on the board and takes whatever chip is currently on the board (thus adding much complexity to bidding).  Scoring is complex, but easily understandable and interestingly designed.  Overall this is a fun game that has a bit too much luck for my taste (but is still thought-provoking enough to be enjoyable).   As with most Knizia games, I got to watch all the other players zoom ahead of me (but had grand fun doing it).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A great throw down game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I’m finding that I’m not a really big fan of most of Reiner Znizia’s designs. Generally speaking, his designs are elegant and simple. However, I find that some of the game play elements in his titles are a little fiddly and usually have many unnecessarily steps and rules that complicate matters. Also, as many have noticed, the themes of his collections feel tacked on. 

I am also of the mind that a purely auction driven game, gets old fast without some other element to help it along. So, going in, “Ra” was already in “probation” from me. I picked up this title based on the strength of its reviews, which is quite substantial. I just had to see what all the fuss is about. At fist the rules seemed over complicated but once we got in the groove of things, as with most games, it became much, much simpler and the game revealed itself. Admittedly, this game was better than what I had expected but certainly not in the leagues of “Puerto Rico,” Caylus” or even “Carcassone.” The game itself is a simple auction game where players bid, using a clever sun mechanism, for tiles which earn them points after each “Epoch.” The player with the most points wins, naturally. Some strategy involved in timing when to use your sun tokens to make a bid, which is the extra little twist in this game. As usual for Knizia, there’s a little scoring math that has to be done but it seems pretty easy to pick up, explain and play. If you like auction games then give it a try, otherwise play “Ra” if you want something meatier than “For Sale.”

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Buy tiles in auction to improve your dynasty for most points.

Plays: More than a dozen.
Type: Auction/trading game = a game where you bid or trade for victory points.
Complexity: Light.
# of players: 3-4.
Playing time: 45 mins.
Player interaction: Competition for scarce resources – tiles. Auctions.
Randomness: Low – tile draw, but you decide what set of tiles to bid on.

Replayability: High. This is one those rare "simple yet deep" games.
Fun: For a number crunching game, this is surprisingly fun, probably because the auctions make it highly interactive. Calling “Ra!” is also fun and something every gamer should get to experience.
Memorability: Low, it’s a VP engine that doesn’t create stories.

Thematic integration: Strained.
Components: Nice.

Who will like this: Family gamers that want to do a bit more thinking.

RATING: 9
Ra is a game I liked at first, despite being terrible at it. Then I began to [i]really[/i] like it and started to want to play it more often. Now, I'm beginning to downright love the game. I hope I'll get to play it on a regular basis.

This is one of the best (the best?) auction games I've played. The mechanisms are ridiculously simple and can be explained in a few minutes. However, the game is wonderfully difficult to play well. The game is "light", but it's unforgiving and punishes slight miscalculations. Wonderful stuff.

RATING: 8

I'm not a big fan of purely auction games, but this one works for me: the once-around bidding is tricky and enjoyable (somewhat similar to Medici in this regard); the system for exchanging bidding tiles is very clever. RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A fine little push-your-luck auction game.  Bid values are limited by sun tiles, auctions can be forced by ra tiles or by other players calling ra and choices are limited by what you pull from the bag: in all these ways, a lot of the tension of the game comes from not being able to do exactly what you wan or need to do.  So you're always waiting for something to happen: sometimes you get lucky; usually, you don't.  This dynamic is mildly interesting.  No Thanks does push-you-luck better.  Biblios does auctions & press-your-luck in a more streamlined fashion that gives player more agency and control.

RATING: 10
This might just be the best - and definitely most accessible - auction game there is. The theme is pasted-on, but why not Egypt... and the rules are VERY well-balanced. The idea of "sun paid by me becomes a property of the player who wins auction after mine" is especially clever, creating another strategic thing to watch out for.

In short, rarely there is a game providing so much space for decisions on so little rules. Some say Knizia's masterpiece is Ingenious, Euphrat and Tigris etc.
For me, while those are a rock-solid games, this is really the peak of his work.
AND unlike Euphrat, this withstands the test of time.

RATING: 8
Fast-paced yet interesting game of competitive push-your-luck. Has the usual knizia hallmarks. I like the sun value mechanic, which is an innovative twist on the auction/opportunity cost problem. It is a feature similarly applied in Hollywood Blockbuster and it worked well in that game, too. I get a bit tired of seeing the usual knizia game element of rewarding players who have the highest bidding currency at the end of the game (eg High Society, Taj Mahal, etc) because it seems like a distraction from the main game, but that's just me. Also, Ra Is a bit too random to take seriously but fun if you accept that skill won't guarantee a win. Good time killer although it's a bit meatier than what I would consider to be a "filler".

RATING: 10
This is my first Euro bidding game, and so far I love it.  This game is so different than any game I own. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
What struck me about Ra is that it's a very simple game to teach. One practice game and I was able to learn and teach the game with little difficulty. Among all the very highly rated games on BGG this would have to be one of the most fundamentally simple games of them all. 

You have 3 simple choices each turn... Call RA which starts an auction, draw a tile which adds to the auction track or use a God tile which enables you to take a tile from the auction track and place it into your area. The mechanisms in this game are dead simple and this certainly deserves it's reputation as THE gateway auction game. The tactics and the strategies in the game take a bit longer to grok but even after a few games I can see there is certainly some subtlety to the auction process. Knowing when to bid and when to call Ra is a balancing act... your actions and how you bid depends heavily on how many large Sun value tiles are still in reserve in other players areas. Some rounds go very quickly with many Ra tiles being called whereas others develop into extended point fests with a large number of great tiles in auction after auction. 

I can see why some feel this game is luck driven and while I agree there is luck... certainly that is mitigated by prudent bidding and the fact that you can often get a high numbered sun tile in return for using a lower numbered sun tile to win an auction for something others didn't really want to pay up for... their loss, your gain. There is certainly a look ahead mechanism in play here which enables you to set yourself up for future epochs even if you don't score big in the current one.

All in all the diversity of tactics you need to consider in Ra are remarkable considering the game mechanisms are dead simple. Again, this is clearly a game that has a very efficient, lean design... an extremely low amount of chrome and a pasting on of theme... but the underlying strong structure of the design allows the gameplay to maintain a brisk pace while everyone pursues their various options to try and achieve a victory by scoring the most fame points.

After all that praise... I have to say this is probably the hardest time I've ever had coming up with a rating for a game. It is solid, decent game but am I having fun? Somewhat. Am I enjoying auction after auction after auction? Somewhat. Do I feel like replaying this often? Not really. This may change with further play but right now I waver between this being a 5, 6 or 7 in the ratings. I believe there are elements of all three of those ratings in Ra... it IS a good game, I will only play it sporadically and it can be slightly boring. On any given day it will range from a 5 to a 7 and sometimes even slightly above that if the session was reasonably interesting and slightly below that if the overly lean, almost skeletal structure of the auction process is allowed to poke its bones through too sharply... making the game too dry and repetitious for its own good.

I rate it a 6 currently and that's maybe a bit high. Time will tell but this could easily drop a half point or rise by a similar measure but the average of my feelings is a 6 currently. That such an efficient and clean design can sometimes feel too simple and sterile is not a surprise I suppose coming from Knizia and his mathematical background... but in Ra it seems to show itself more starkly than in some of his other games it seems to me. 

Ra possibly would have been better as part of another game with 1 or 2 other meshing mechanisms to help it bridge the gap to make it more complex and interesting and not "just" an auction game. Maybe I just need to play it more and really appreciate it for the "classic" design that it is. Time will tell... but my gut feeling right now is that like the monuments depicted on the tiles of Ra... the game may well be a classic but at the same time it's also a dry and weathered specimen from the past.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A classic auction game that's very simple, yet have all those decision moments that other games have to invent complex mechanisms to accomplish. Initiate bidding when the pool is valuable enough for you (or before it gets too valuable for your opponents) or press your luck and pass. Offer bid tiles to build combinations but also consider the bid tile you get in return as it puts you in a better or worse position next epoch. So deep and yet so smooth and simple and a great introduction to non-gamers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Ra is a game I used to like 10 years ago. Since then it stayed a long time on the shelf, because I have a lot of other games to play. 
I remember I liked the game, especially the fact that it is an open game: no hidden elements here. You can always compare your own position to that of your opponents and adapt your tactics to it.

Now, years later the game felt a bit disappointing. I  have multiple explanations for this change in feel about Ra. Maybe it's because some fellow players just didn't find it their cup of tea and unintentionally took away the fun of the game. Maybe my preference changed overtime. The game now feels a little too abstract to me (I don't really like abstract games). The best reason I can find is that in the meantime I simply discovered a lot of games that are just more fun!

It isn't a bad game though and it has the advantage of a short game length and it is pretty quick to learn.

I enjoy this game, just not quite as much as Modern Art and Hollywood Blockbuster. I think this is more about who I play with, and we never get 4 players though.  Maybe some day.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ra is a real achievement in game design.  It has such simple mechanics, but they offer so many unusual twists on the standard auction game that the game really seems unlike any other.  Perhaps my favorite aspect is that, as part of the auction lot, you are bidding on the sun that was used to win the previous lot.  Ra also packs a great deal of strategy and tactics into a really short playtime, such that it is the densest game I own, in terms of depth per playing time.

Ra can be prone to some crazy circumstances, due to the way the tiles come out of the bag, but these fluke occurences don't bother me that much.  The fact that they happen actually serves to keep you on your toes as your playing.  You never know exactly what will happen, and just because only 2 ra tiles have been pulled, that doesn't mean that the epoch will continue for much longer.  Ra is a wonderful game, and I would gladly play it just about any time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Overall Comment: a different kind of auction game where players compete for tiles to add to their collections, these tiles gain the players points if sets of the same or different are collected. There is nothing else to this game other than the bidding.

Ratings:
Initial(wow factor): 7 (not much to look at)
Family: 8 (everyone will play this one but it is not requested much anymore except by the young ones)
Game group: 7 (filler play only)
AP: 8 (not much slow down once players are familiar with the tiles)
Solo play: not yet developed

When purchased: 2007
Recommend expansions: none available
Age range: 6+
Luck factor(1-10high): 7 (drawing tiles from a bag)

Reason purchased: Geek analysis and looking for a good gateway game

Pros: plays quick and is somewhat interesting, better than playing cards with a group of adults but has the same feel, conversation during play
Cons: same everytime (just like cards)

Recommendation: if you like cards then this should work for you, not much to think about and the turns go quick. An adult game night with RA is usually good fun.
Replay rating: Below average
Game value (plays/cost ratio): above average (played very heavily initially and the game group latched onto it - excellent time filler game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Knizia's auction game in ancient Egypt. Everyone is seeded with 3 bid tokens, with different values. Bid on pharohs, monuments, gods, water, civilization tokens, etc. Being a Kniza game, there are many ways to earn points (or lose them) Not being a huge fan of bidding games, it took me 4 or 5 games to catch on this game. I really enjoy this game now and it is my favourite of all the auction games out there. It is a very tense, strategic and subtle game. There will be tough decisions on when to invoke Ra. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
UPDATE: After 6 years finally played it properly. Love it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Bidding system game where you bid on pieces.  You have to collect certain pieces each turn to avoid penalties while trying to collect points.  People tend to have a bit of trouble keeping track of what they need to get for what kinds of points.  Printing out cheat sheets (play mats) for this makes it easier.

RATING: 10
I obtained this rather late (2003). Since then, I really enjoy the game. It has a clever auction mechanics i.e. initiating auction, distinct bidding tiles and bidding for future auction power together with well-thought multiple-way-to-the-victory scoring system. First the scoring system seemed rather cumbersome but in fact it is very easy once I understand what will be kept throughout the game. (people explained to me didnt emphersize this so i was totally lost first. Now I make sure everyone understand temporal and permanent tiles when I teach this to new plaers...) Anyway it is really a great game and should be re^published as a card game soon.

RATING: 9.2
An ingenious bidding system (players receive fixed value tiles and a limited number of possible won auctions) combines with an ingenious selection of goods up for bids (not only tiles that vary in value greatly depending on circumstances, but you're also bidding on a bidding tile for the next round). Not Knizia's "purest" game, but possibly his game that best combines clever yet simple mechanics with a great sense of tension and fun. More dynamic than any other auction game I can think of.

RATING: 10
This game Ra-ocks!  Simple, fast, but with elements of balance that mean you need to pay attention to all phases of the game.  Anyone can learn this game in 5 minutes, and players of mixed experience can play together easily.  I love that your buying power changes as you buy . . . great mechanic.

I'm not sure what all the hype is about getting the english Rio Grande version . . . but I guess that's a collectors thing, as I play games just to play games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ra is a remarkably simple game. Other than how the tiles affect scoring, there is little to for new players to learn. Decisions on one's turn is limited to either bet on the existing row of tiles or draw a new tile to add to it.

On the downside, the Egyptian theme is as flimsy as can be, offering little more than images for the tiles to carry. Also, this 2nd edition's tiles are somewhat hard to distinguish due to murky colors and artwork. For all the garish primary colors the 1st edition had, at least one could tell the tiles apart from across the table.

So where is the engagement in Ra? Strangely enough its not in either of the main mechanics of Auction/Bidding and Set Collection, but rather in a Push-Your-Luck element created by when would be the best time to start an auction. As more tiles are placed in the auction row, interest, and tension builds.

All-in-all, Ra is a good game, but there are many I prefer over it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

An impressive feat for a game that is very weakly tied to it's theme.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I like this game for a lot of reasons. It provides a very limited set of decisions that opens up into a very wide emergent interaction space. The fixed value sun tiles and single action limit (invoking Ra or drawing a new tile from the bag) force the players into a tight arena that allows them to deftly maneuver around the clever scoring system--and each other. 

I was surprised (stupidly, because I always find Knizia's big box games thematic) how much I got into the theme. The scoring of tiles at the end of the round is really rich in narrative, and it makes would otherwise be a complex euro metric easy to remember; Pharaohs fight for rulership, civilization building is required (and rewarded), the Nile farmland is prosperous (but only after floods), and so on. Just beautiful. 

This game also appears to me in a tactile way. I love grabbing the Ra idol and slamming it down on the table with a shout; I love thwacking my sun tiles down to bid. I love trading in god tiles; I love collecting my auction winnings by sliding them off the board. The game provides a certain sequence of somatic (and verbal: "RA!") actions that just appeal to my simian sapience. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A tense, yet fun game of bidding and taking risks, that usually moves pretty quickly with little downtime.  Has the perfect amount of random chance, in my book.  I enjoy playing this game even when I'm not doing particularly well :)

Why an "8" rating and not a "9"?  Because new players often draw tiles recklessly and refuse to start auctions, which can throw the game to the players that follow them in turn order.  The unusually low ratings from some geeks are probably due to the fact that some people don't understand a key strategy in this game: that players with low valued bidding tiles aren't powerless -- they always have the option to start auctions and force other players to make difficult decisions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very round offering, Ra brings yet another interesting couple of twists to auction games: throughout three eras players bid for tiles that will be collected in sets for later scoring, but they don't come in fixed lots - each turn a new tile can be added, or the auction can be called (or triggered by a special tile). Plus, bids are made only with a single chip out of the modest pool a player gets for each era. The winning chip will replace a chip open for all to see, that will belong to the auction winner only for scoring purposes.

It takes a couple of plays to get truly acquainted with the scoring system (balanced but a bit messier than Modern Art, for instance). Once this is done, Ra offers interesting decisions at a leisurely pace and resorting to very little material; after overloading things a bit with Euphrat & Tigris Knizia was sticking clearly to his guns on this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I played this for the first time after introducing our group to Medici the week prior. Gosh, I waited two years for this?! After hearing all the great things about "best auction game ever" I was sorely let down. The auctions were never tense - since usually only 1 or 2 players were in a position to both benefit from AND win the auction - and the scoring was complicated enough that it was difficult to appropriately value the tiles in play, even for the analytical memebers of our group. Compare that to Medici where nearly every bid would lead to groans from the next player (meaning a great bid!) and relative values of cards would continue to diverge for players as they specialized in commodities (resulting in tough decision on whether to jack up the price or let them have it). For us Medici was way better.

RATING: 8
It's a really great game, but the latest reprint is plain garbage. The art is passable, but it's non functional, because you can't easily tell the tiles apart. The tiles do not fit in the bag and it is impossible to shuffle them in the bag, which is very important in this game. You can't close the box without throwing away the useless insert. On top of it all, it costs almost $50. Overall, very disappointed. 
The game itself is very good and is deeper than it seems. Not as good with 2, 3-4 players is the sweet spot.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Ra[/b] was traded away in a math trade 10/5/15. (Received Elysium)
Received in a math trade (11/10/14).

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (8):[/COLOR]

[i]For a time this had become my favorite auction game (replacing Knizia's Medici), but has since been replaced by Modern Art (another Knizia classic). Out of the 3 I still think this is the easiest for new players to grasp, especially since everyone has bidding tiles so it is really hard to completely mess up the economy of the game, where as in a game like Modern Art a really bad bid can hand someone the game. There is also a lot of decisions to make in the tiles you decide to collect because there is no way you can do everything, and on top of that you can lose points if you fail to collect any tiles of certain groups. 

Ra ended up leaving my collection because my family had no interest in playing it and a lot of the other people I game with have copies. I still consider it an excellent game and one I am always willing to play. In my opinion Ra it is the closest to a gateway/family game when considering Knizia's auction games (I think For Sale is the best when considering other designers).[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (8):[/COLOR]

[i]- Bidding tiles: obviously this is what makes the game. You can only bid with one of the 3 tiles you have in your hand which is extremely difficult since you may end up over paying for a group of tiles.
- Set collection: I always enjoy this mechanic in a game.
- Ra: Again there is a time crunch because once the Ra figure reaches the end of the track that round of bidding is over. This becomes especially stressful when yo are the only person pulling tiles/bidding at the end of a round [i](do I take another tile and chance getting nothing if I pull a Ra tile?)[/i].

This is an excellent game that I can see becoming a classic with more plays.
I am really looking forward to introducing this one to my family, I think it will be a great step up in auction games from For Sale.[/i]

RATING: 8
Un clásico de subastas de Reiner Knizia, simple, elegante y lleno de decisiones interesantes. Con momentos de particular tensión y la dosis justa de aleatoriedad. Nunca te imaginaste invocando a "Ra!!" con tanto entusiasmo. En su momento me cansé de recomendarlo, cuando tenía una edición de un precio accesible. Ahora hay que debatirse entre copias de segunda mano y una nueva edición sobreproducida.

Estos títulos más viejos te hacen recordar la época en que los euros no necesitaban mil componentes y un arte sobreproducido para ser extraordinarios. La mecánica del Ra es elaborada sin ser complicada y su dinámica es atrapante sin ninguna pretensión temática.

Muy recomendable  8+
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Great gateway game! Unique auction mechanic and tile collecting, make this...one outstanding medium weight game! This one doesn't come out all the time...but when it does it is always an enjoyable experience! Wonderful to show new gamers...not always their favorite (i.e. doesn't get requested again and again)...but, they never mind the game and appreciate the new experience!

Lay out tiles, once per turn! If a red Ra tile is drawn or someone calls Ra, then everyone must bid or pass on the offer of tiles! It might be just one tile or several...but save your sacred 3 bids for when it counts!

RATING: 10
Show some love as Ra plays great with 3, 4 and 5 players!  

I enjoy the balance of short and long term scoring, bidding and resource management along with the fact that you bid with your sun tiles which the next bid winner will then have for the next turn.

Add the fact that it can easily play in under an hour and it's one of my favorites. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Reiner must own a cardboard tile emporium because every one of his games has a billion tiles! Ra has 180! I was finally able to play this brilliant auction game at a friend's and I loved it. The mechanics are simple and elegant: set collection, press-your-luck, and once-around-the-table auction. Actions are just as easy to understand: add one more tile to the auction or call for the auction. Collecting different sets of tiles means that there are numerous strategies and multiple paths to victory. The game play is intuitive, fast and there's no downtime between player's turns...everyone's waiting to see the next tile! Ra is a classic game because new players can learn and understand the game fairly quickly (scoring is a little intricate) and experienced players can experiment with different strategies. Maybe the game is halfway between a trick-taking card game and an auction of set collection. The center of the game is the question of what people consider "a good bargain" for a set of tiles. Fast and light, Ra is a fantastic blend of simple yet elegant mechanics, keeping everyone engaged and coming back to play again!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Considered by many as THE auction game from Knizia. Simlpe mechanics and easy to learn and teach. Plenty of strategic choices - and one must know the mind of it's opponents to win. Good fun. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a very good game design, an unique way to handle the auctions mechanics. There is a clever set collection mechanics also. Nongamers love it. Fast setup, 60 minutes to play. Skill is rewarded in a 3 player game, but fun will be there anyway for any number of players.

Unfortunately, after some time it becomes a little repetitive to my taste. I can play every once in a while, but I traded my copy for a game I will play more often (China).

RATING: 7
This was our go-to evening-ending filler game for many years. Crazy fast game (even though it can take an hour to play with a full 5), great decisions, lots of angst and eye-rolling. Punishing to new players in an experienced group. Can sometimes result in one player having the perfect run of tiles *and* the right sun tokens at the right time. Mostly it's both a great game exercise and a great lesson in the economics of opportunity costs.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
50+ plays. Arguably the greatest 3 player auction game of all time. Placing future bidding power into the auction pile is a masterstroke. Limiting each auction to once around, and restricting each player to 4 (or 3) wins each round is key to making a fast moving game. Oodles of luck in determining the contents of the auction pile provide the fun and drama, as well as the continual challenge in determining what's the right bid given what's in it, how far into the round you are, and other player's collection so far. All in all, eminently replayable.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An auction/bidding classic.  Each turn, the choice is simply draw a tile or call an auction.  But somehow even with such a simple decision to make, the game provides a wealth of depth. You are constantly evaluating what your opponents are going for and what the offer is worth to everyone.  The different viable paths of scoring are well balanced and the sun token system for bidding markers is simply brilliant.  Easily one of Knizia's best.  It's icing on the cake that this game even works with 2 players.  There is probably more support for Tigris and Euphrates, but I think Ra may be Knizia's masterpiece.

RATING: 10
A truly rare brand of awesomeness. This game is highly strategic, and while it could be boiled down to a series of probability-based decisions, the variables are too numerous to calculate, so you find yourself "feeling out" the boundary between deciding one way or the other. Thus, the game-play is more intuitive than cerebral.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
RA is always exciting. I've won by totally different strategies and also lost by the same strategies.  Because the worth of the pot is always is different for each player, and the worth of the suns decreases as more RA tiles are drawn, and each player has a different set of suns, it never becomes 'simple' to evaluate.  RA is particularly interactive, with no downtime whatsoever, and all players constantly watching to see what tile is drawn, scheming and bluffing to complete their set of tiles.

Also, RA is very well themed!  Go read a history of ancient Egypt, or listen to one: http://www.teach12.com/ttcx/coursedesclong2.aspx?cid=350&pc=History%20-%20Ancient%20and%20Medieval .  It is all there in Knizia's game, in proportion, consistent and elegant, with great art.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Ra is a very subtle game, that seems simple on the surface, but really has quite a bit of depth.  The bidding system with open bid markers with discrete values really defines the game, you really need to pay attention to what other people need and how they would value tiles, but at the same time, be mindful that you can only win 3 lots yourself, and if you wait too long, you might not even get that many.  While there is certainly a random element, there's a ton of tension in this game, and I love it.

(5+ plays)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My favourite auction game.

The core of the game are the multiple scoring categories. Each player can specialize on a subset of these, which means that every set of tiles has a different value for each player. You're constantly trying to estimate what other people would pay for the lot versus what you are able to pay. After that, you hav to take the available suns into account too.

Ra has a perfect balance of predictability and randomness. Determining the value of a tile is part calculation, part intuition.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ra can be a bit dry...like doing a math puzzle.  But it's well balanced and good entertainment for analytical types.  

On the one hand, it's almost like an "auction game for dummies," in the sense that you don't have to do the valuation and set a bid amount yourself, but rather you have to look at your discrete available bid tokens and decide whether or not to trade one for the goods being offered.  

On the other hand, Ra balances this simplified bidding structure by complicating the lot offerings, and by adding the threat of the round ending before you've made your bids.  What you're offering is easy to process.  What you're really buying is far more difficult, as there are too many sources of points available for you to score them all.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I love the mechanism with the suns [i](the "money")[/i] used being placed in the middle for another [i](or the same)[/i] player to take in the next auction. There's lots to think about but it's not really [i]that[/i] heavy so it plays fast and furious and everybody's happy.

RATING: 7.5

RATING: 10
Keeps going up from 7 and has finally peaked.  Strategy becomes more apparent with repeated plays.  I don't see so much luck involved in this game as high vs. low-risk decisions and probability.  Thoughtless acts tend to have no reward, and well thought out decisions have a good reward.  Very easy to teach to non-gamers.  Easily my favorite Knizia. I love the tough decisions, the myriad options, the speed, and the ease with which it makes it to the game table.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ra is a game pf both luck and planning with a Egyptian theme.  The players draw cardboard tiles from a bag and place them on the game board or in front of them.  Some tiles must be discarded after each round and others can be saved up until the end of the game which lasts 3 phases.

The components are as follows: tiles are cardboard while both the sun tokens (read currency) and the special event Ra token are wood.  There is also a canvas bag included that is hardly big enough in my version of the game to hold all the cardboard tiles.


This game and Small World have re-introduced board gaming to my family!  Bravo.

RATING: 10
I find this game quite compelling.  The components are wonderful--particularly the Sun tiles.  The complaints I hear and read about RA tiles occuring too frequently seem to indicate some people just don't appreciate the delicate danger of calling RA too much (and getting stuck at the end as others get a tile buffet) or calling RA too little (and watching the high-number sun tiles become devastatingly powerful). VERY TASTY decisions to be made here and enough flavor/theme (IMHO) to put it among the great greats.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
That's it; I'm giving Ra a 10. It's perfect. A pure auction game with so much depth that it makes you forget you're playing an auction game. I originally rated it an 8, but it gets so much better the more you play it. It's even great fun played against the computer. A perfect 10 it is!

Ra is easy to learn - but hard to master. At first it seems a bit weird and random. Bidding is unusual and abstract; you don't bid money, or points, but these sun tiles. How much are they worth?

You think that that's the key to Ra - as with almost all auction games: figuring out how much to bid on any given lot. The fact that you have to put a value on your suns as well as the tiles up for auction makes it a bit more complex, but something you'll figure out with a few more plays, right? (Already addicted!)

And then, with a few more plays, you realize you can't really put a value on your suns. You can now on the tiles, but now you understand that when figuring out which sun to bid, your position in respect to the other players is as much, if not more, important than the auctioned tiles.

And then it hits you: the most important skill in playing Ra is not correctly estimating the value of the tiles, but manipulating your position. It's not multiplayer solitaire. Everything is useful information. You look around you, and see whose position is strong and whose is weak, and what needs to happen for your position to improve. The ability to invoke Ra is your most powerful - your only weapon. You can use it to completely change the situation on the board. Yes, this a real boardgame.

The player to your right just turned over a flood tile - a tile he'd like to have. He has the 3, 5 and 12 suns. You have the 4. Smiling, you reach for the Ra figure, and you realize just how much you love this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
One of the most streamlined auction mechanics around, and the Ra tiles counting down the end of round makes this game tense. Although the tile draws have some narrative, the game play isn't evocative of Egyptian theme. As usual there are many avenues to gain points,but here it is a busy metropolis (gods=2pts,most pharoahs=5pts etc) and if in a competitive attitude, determining the how far ahead players are is cumbersome. This is essential to do as you need to assess the values of drawn tiles which you will also need to take into account various tile type distribution of what has gone (if you can remember) and what is left. If you do the maths or don't, ultimately this is a game of psychology between bidders as to the probability/belief of what will be drawn in future, which can result in tile draws being unfair (especially the disaster tiles adds pain, hope & fun). If you can get over this punitive aspect, it will no doubt add more tension next time you play. Me, I would rather play something less mathematical to play and resolve, and with a shorter playing time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Nice game. Usually do not like 'pushing your luck' type of games, but this one worked for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
-

A great auction game with great mechanics and flow, which I enjoy everytime I play it.  However, in my opinion it does not deserve a higher score than 8 because of its chaotic nature.

Neither strategy not tactics allow a player to edge out the equally proficient opponents in a satisfactoy way. The randomness of the tiles drawn (especially the 'Ra' tiles) and the equally random timing of an opponent to call "Ra" (from the point of view of the rest of the players) makes for a fairly random and chaotic game with unpredictable results. This is true whether you have played the game many times or you just learned it.

Of course careful examination of the opponents' holdings and their remaining bidding tiles allow for a certain degree of tactics and strategical planning, but still not sufficiently. In other words, hard analysis and hard planning do not necessarily reward a player proportionally.

-

RATING: 7
This is a good auction game, which orignal mechanisms in that not only are you bidding on tiles you need, you are also swapping out the currency marker you use to bid with, for whatever value marker was last used to win a bid. The sets of tiles score in different ways, with some flushing at the end of the phase and some staying with you. It's fun to play once in awhile, but the game doesn't have anything outside it's core mechanism (which it does very well), but I find myself wanting more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
What I like about it is that you make only one choice each turn: draw a tile or invoke Ra. But that seemingly simple choice requires you to evaluate a whole host of factors - which tiles are already laid out in the middle, which tiles you and your opponents have, which Suns you and your opponents have, how many points you and your opponents have, how close the round is to ending. And these evaluations shift with every new tile that is drawn. 

It's a game where you have to be constantly thinking about your opponents and presenting them with difficult choices - to spend a Sun that's higher than they'd really like or see a juicy lot go to someone they really don't want to have it. A masterpiece of emergent design - a few simple rules and a scoring mechanism, let the players do the rest.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
One of the games in the 'Knizia Auction Trilogy'; considering that this appellation is not from Knizia himself, and he has made probably a dozen auction games, I don't care much for this label, as the games have no connection besides some vaguely shared elements.

A key portion of this game is that you draw a tile during your turn, and then decide whether to invoke Ra (start an auction for all tiles on the board); this process slows down the game significantly (probably doubling the length of turns that really are a decision-less random tile drawing, which makes the game feel clunky in a way that has nothing to do with the actual gameplay. You make auctions for tiles in three rounds, scoring some tiles at the end of each round (some of which are kept in your tableau, others discarded, and some saved and only scored at game's end), and in the end whoever has the VP is the victory. 

There are some neat bits and pieces to this game, and it has the usual Knizia vibe, but overall the game feels sorta clunky all over, and I'd much rather get a quick game of Modern Art or even Colossal Arena than play this again. The tiles really could be cards in a deck, or just stacked tiles, and it'd streamline that problematic aspect, I think that issue prevents me from being able to appreciate the game proper more critically.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Raaaaaa!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A good auction game - one that I'm always willing to play.
The limited sun tiles make the game (beside being a good looking component). Do you call an auction to force others to bid before the stack builds up or that you may be able to use on of your poor tiles to snag something. Do you try to force others out so you can draw lots of tiles at the end. 
A lot of good decisions, can see why it is so highly ranked.

RATING: 8.5
One of the best auction game out there. The game is simple yet tactical. You realy need to have an eye on what your opponents are doing. You then have the difficult choice of trying to optimize your game while trying to steel a good hands for your opponents in order to stop one of them to be a runaway leader and try to make the best of what you have been able to get. There is no down time has you are always analysing you hand and the one of other players and bid on auctions. The rules are clear and simple. The material is O.K. One of the best Knizia game. 

Un des meilleurs jeu d'enchères sur le marché. Vous devez vraiment garder un oeil sur vos opposants et vous avez la tâche difficile d'essayer d'optimizer votre main tout en tentant de voler une bonne main à vos opposants afin d'éviter qu'un joueur ne s'échappe avec la victoire; vous devez donc faire le mieu avec ce que vous avez obtenu àa l'enchère. Il n'y a pas de temps d'attente dans ce jeu car vous devez analyser votre main ainsi que celle des autres joueurs et participer aux enchères. Le jeu est simple et tactique en même temps. Les règles sont claires et le matériel est O.K. Un des meilleurs jeu de Knizia.

RATING: 6

Getting pretty lucky (or having your opponents get unlucky) seems more likely to lead to good outcomes than good play. Still it's relatively quick and it is at least fun to play and try to best your opponents. Will enjoy from time to time, but just not a game I see myself thinking deeply over the strategy which is the main element I find in games I really love.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Ra was one of those games that Knizia published during his "golden" period, the era that cemented him as game designer [i]par excellence[/i].  And it's pretty darned good.

It's a push-your-luck auction game.  Players draw tiles from a bag which then go into a pool.  If a player draws a Ra tile it forces an auction, alternatively a player can choose to start an auction rather than draw a tile.

When Ra comes around, the tiles in the pool are auctioned off.  Each player can only win a maximum of three bids per round.  They bid by offering a Sun token which will have a unique number on it (Sun tokens are numbered 1 through 16 and the way these tokens cycle between players is particularly ingenious).  The tiles that you win at auction combine in various ways to provide points.  Some tiles are actually bad.  You will also lose points if you don't have certain tiles at the end of a round.  The complexities of trying to figure out how valuable a set of tiles is to yourself and your opponents are various and subtle so I'm not going to go into them.  But they make for a very enjoyable game.

But wait, there's more!  This is also a push-your-luck game.  Every time a Ra tile is drawn it is placed on the Ra track.  If the track fills up the round ends immediately, no matter how many Sun tokens you still have available for bidding.  It's not uncommon for a single player to be left in a round, drawing tiles from the bag, hoping for an uncontested windfall, with the other players hoping he draws a freakin' Ra tile already.

I find there to be many similarities between Ra and [GameId=46].  So many, in fact, that Medici feels like a subset of Ra, a boring tedious subset that doesn't even play in a shorter amount of time.  

Luck can be a factor in Ra.  I've seen games where, in absolute denial of the law of probabilities, a player pulled out a string of awesome tiles after the other players had bid their last.  Your mileage may vary, but I like push-you-luck games and this element of Ra is just another wonderful piece of an overall great game.

(By the way, what's with the home made player mats?  All the info is already on the board and is easy for all to see.  Why make an elegant game fiddly and take up too much table space?)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.9
Intriguing bidding game with winning theme for our group. We would play this almost any opportunity.
It's fascinating how much is going on (looking at what other people are collecting, monitoring their available suns, the auction track and Ra track, etc) while on the surface you're just pulling a tile and placing on the track. If you don't play alertly/strategically, you could almost miss the majority of the game lying below the surface.

After many plays through the years, with different groups (gamer and non-gamer), Ra never fails to impress with design, simplicity, and depth of choices.

RATING: 7.1
I like the variety of ways to score points, and the multiple options to consider when deciding what to try for and what to bid on it.  It gives a feel of Lucca Citta for the huge number of different things you have to think about in making your decisions, therefore making the decisions so tough.  Do you take what works for you now, or wait for something better, or stop another player from getting something that really helps?  And don't forget this, that, and the other thing you have to take care of before the epoch is over!  Will there be enough time to get what you need? The auction method is a very interesting technique.  I love the way a player with bad numbers can still take home better tiles than other players through intelligent manipulation of the auction.  (Don't expect me to tell you my strategy, but I won my last game 45 to 33 to x to y to 21. Subtracting the starting 10 points, that was 35 to 11.)  Very good game, in my opinion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really enjoy how auctions work in this game.  The combination of unique sun tokens with bidding on both the lot and the sun token result in a very elegant auction mechanic that has a different feel from all the other auction games I've played. 

The whole concept of knowing which players can beat your best token, or how your second best token makes certain players have to use their best token, and how all of that plays in to when you call Ra and when you keep growing the pot is great, and also provides for fast moving game play, which I also enjoy.

I also like that it's relatively easy to get a handle of all the information in the game.  In so many games it is beneficial to memorize card distributions, but this game makes it all simple, putting the numbers of tiles on the board and allowing you to glance at what people have to realize there is only one more of that last monument type left.  It's great to be able to do analysis on this level on your first or second play of the game!

And finally there is that small amount of "press your luck" built in to each game when all the players are out of tokens but one, and they decide how far to draw while tempting the fates of a final Ra tile.  Sometimes it's great to be that last person and worth holding back, other times it's a total let down, and still other times you get that last ra token and start cursing your own greediness!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A simple yet addictive auction game. I really like the way players not only bid on the tiles they want, but also the bidding tokens they want in the next round. You can definitely tell this is a Knizia game since players who are a little more math-oriented will tend to find the right strategy. I find there's just the right balance between all the different scoring methods.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Played once (tonight). I really enjoyed it. It might be worth a 6 or 7.

It's a pure and tight  - yet very random - set collection and auction game with some nice nuances to make it thinky and help you feel like you're building a nice points engine.

My concern is that there are a lot of adding-up chores you can do in the game (if you can be bothered) to increase your chances of winning. All the information about available tiles is revealed as the game progresses. This means it becomes increasingly important to remain aware (by adding-up a lot of things) of whether tiles you and other players need are still available.  It does take a lot of the fun out of the 'push your luck' element of the game, as any serious player might say "can you wait for five minutes while I tally-up what's must still be available for us in the tile bag and cross-reference it with what each of us still needs".

Despite that reservation, it flowed well and was fun.

RATING: 6
What a great game!  I love this game because it is so simply, yet so complex.  Either draw a new tile, or bid for the existing tiles.  A simple decision altered by a million considerations.  What tiles help me the most?  Do i want to keep the tiles from someone else?  Should I use my low tiles to put pressure on those with high tiles?  This gets my highest rating based on the heavy decision making that occurs during the game.  It's also a game I don't think I would ever be able to turn down if offered to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I am not such a big fan of set-collection games and the scoring in Ra is pure set collection. But the central auction mechanism is really elegant and leads to a lot of hard decisions. I like that there is also a push-your-luck aspect, because near the end of a round you do not if you should go for more tiles or avoid the last red one by bidding on a smaller set of tiles. Of Knizia's bidding games that I know (besides Ra also Amun Re, Strozzi, Modern Art/Masters Gallery) I like Ra the most.

Although the game is almost abstract, the little of what is left of the Egyptian theme helps to remember some of the rules (for example that pharaos and buildings do not vanish after the round).

RATING: 8.75
Low numbered tiles can be as valuable as high ones, call Ra often with them. Large scoring of the monuments in round 3 will always trump other strategies. Don't hesitate to call Ra just to trade up tokens in round 3.  When bidding for tokens that are retained from round to round, remember that these are 3x as valuable in round 1 vs round 3, because they are scored all three times.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.52
No surprises here, Knizia has done this sort of thing elsewhere. Players bid in successive rounds for different tiles: monuments, pharoahs, civilizations, etc. These score points (or lose) them in various combinations. Players need to optimise their score, highest wins at the end.
The mechanisms are quite clever, the game relatively short, and the theme fairly engaging.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Cool game. Takes a lot of thought and planning.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
http://www.ronkkonen.com/boardgames.html#Ra_1
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pulling tiles out of the RA bag is like pulling sweets out of a halloween bag--you hate some and love others, but they are all shiny, pretty, fun to look at.  The tiles are grown-up candy--iconic artifacts of culture, disaster, religion, weathered monuments, impending midnight, each with its unique flavor.  RA involves a lot of pulling tiles, and this helps brighten what would otherwise be an extremely dry game.  It took me a couple plays to get into RA.  Though the rules are simple, the scoring system will take a bit of time to remember.  After I got past that hump (2 games or so), it became a brisk, simple game of hoping for the right tiles, taking risks, trying to guess other players' actions, doing a little ez calculation of numbers.  For a 30-45 min game, it is just about the perfect mix of mental exertion, luck, and sweatiness.  

A lightish game good for gamers, but I question how good it is with non-gamers--there's a 1-2 game learning curve because the rules are a little complex, and because you need to get a feel for the mix of tiles in the bag.  So it hits kind of a strange niche.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I feel this is better than Modern Art, despite the latter being more opaque. Perhaps it is because the fixed price value tiles in Ra truly give you avenues of outplaying your opponent, whereas the freedom of Modern Art feels more of an arbitrary bidding experience. Both are works of elegance, but Ra is slightly more fun.

RATING: 9
Knizia's greatest.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Oohh... I could play this coldly analytic and brutally, I could play this drunk at high speed screaming, I could play this anyway. Auction game crossed with chicken. Wow. I've started playing this on BSW and blinked and it's 7 games later and the sun's coming up...

UPDATE: Years have gone by since I wrote the above and my affection for this game has only grown. It's probably the Euro I've played the most. The absolute subtlety of the decisions - of sizing the lot, of drawing out other people's coins, of forcing people to pay just a little more than they would have hoped, of making a lot just a little too small for somebody to be willing to play... god, it's like sex. The emotional fluidity required to play this well... I've learned about my emotional flaws from this game.

RATING: 10
Another of the best-of-the-best gamer's games.  The fact that the piece used to win a bid becomes a part of the next bid is extremely clever, and the one-round bidding prevents the trouble of aggressive play, allowing the player who is last in bidding to avoid dealing with a bad choice for their play.  Everything about this game, even the random tile choices, is enjoyable.

RATING: 7
I like that the auction mechanic is all "open". You know exactly what you're bidding for and against and with what. You also know the same information for your opponents.

Keeping track of tile types and scoring methods is too hard in early plays. As usual, Knizia's complexity comes in scoring, which is too abstract to be intuitive on early plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
----------

I'm normally not a huge fan of auction games, but Ra's multiple scoring paths make the game fun for me.  There are several strategies you can take:  investing in the long-term (i.e. monuments and rivers), or trying to get points round-by-round through the disposable tiles.  

There's a lot to consider here, and the game presents some pretty tough decisions.  This would make a great family game over the holidays.

RATING: 9
Egyszerű (akár non-gamernek is ajánlanám), logikus, ezerféle, analízis-paralízis őrület felé kergető.
Knizia mester a 2000-es évek környékén ontotta magából az ilyen jellemzőjű, nívós játékokat. Nem jellemzőek a lefutott partik (ha valakit frusztrálnak a játékok, amibe nem lehet hibázni, hát íme a megoldás).
Néha kicsit Can't Stop utóérzet itatja át. Annak ellenére, hogy licitálós ajánlanám azoknak is, akik nem rajonganak az aukciókért. Tisztán átlátható, hogy kinek mik a lehetőségei, szépen, precízen felépített játék a Ra, abszolút hozzáillő, egyszerű grafikával.
Ha valamit meg kellene változtatni a játékkal kapcsolatban, akkor az biztos, hogy nálam a neve lenne! Borzasztó, hogy mennyire "nem kereshető". Maga a társas megelőzte a korát, ma is megállja a helyét, de a Google érában a kétbetűs név rögtön "lebuktatja".

http://boardgamegeek.com/blogpost/24726/ra-kritika

RATING: 7.5
Another satisfying Knizia game.  I didn't quite get the theme entirely, but whatever.  It's enjoyable, reasonably quick, and pretty.  Largely (though not entirely) luck driven.  Like most tile drawing games, I'm not driven to play so much because the gameplay is largely a factor of what comes out of the bag--though admittedly a larger part may be in the timing and execution of players' moves in response to those tiles.  It also seems to me that, aside from the luck thing (which can be a drag sometimes), seating position can matter a lot, and help you or hurt you--particularly as it relates to who has what tiles, who is looking for what, what you are looking for, etc.  I guess that's the breaks, though.  It's still fun to play--though I don't think I would keep it in heavy rotation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

However, the mix of push your luck with open bidding is an intriguing system. And, I like an auction game where you are not bidding victory points: it removes nickel and dimeing from the game.

RATING: 5
I've never been a fan of auction games, so I may be a bit biased, but I didn't much enjoy RA. While the theme fascinates me and the components are all very high quality, scoring is incredibly confusing (to me, anyway).  Thankfully the person who owned the game had printed out some nice "placemats" which had a place to put each of the tiles, and the scording sytem sort of explained on it.  Without the placemats, the game would be way more confusing, I think, than it has any right to be.  With such a complicated scoring system, it makes it very difficult to have a decent idea of how much a partiular lot is really worth when you go bid.  Not to mention the fact that if you happen to with 4 early auction rounds, you essentially sit around doing nothing for 20 minutes or so until the other players finish.  I might play this one again, but I'd rather not.

RATING: N/A
E3  Bill Nitsche
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'd heard that Ra was THE auction game.  Me?  I'm not all that fussed by auction games.  I don't NOT like them - in fact I can quite enjoy them.  It's just that they don't seem to really grab me and shake me all about.  

At first having the rules explained to me I was a little "hmmmmm".  But that all changed when after about half a round it all fell into place and I just love it.  Now in a humble opinion of my very own - this is THE auction game.

This game just works.  The auctioning is quick, beautiful and so very simple.  It's unlike other auction games which can suffer from players trying desperately to analyse and calculate what should be bid for a given set of tiles - and spend painful amounts of time figuring out EXACTLY what should be bid - Ra doesn't suffer from this as the bidding tokens do not have an exact calculable value.  My "10" token beats your "5" token.  It's not twice as good, it's not worth twice as much and I can't demand to get twice as many tiles off the track for it.  It just beats it and that's all.  You can successfully play intuitively (which I adore) and it flows so very smoothly.

I find it so elegant and I adore it.

On another note:  Uberplay have done a great job with the reprint.  Quality components and a box that is just the right space for said components without filling up with air.  Very nice.

My wife is a big fan too, which helps.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Not a big fan of auction games, since they require repeated plays to get a feel for valuations, but Ra is simple and straightforward enough that this problem doesn't come up. Great for 3 players. Wouldn't call this a gateway game though, because the scoring system can put people off, but it's definitely a good introductory auction game. Problem is it feels dry. Completely abstract.

--------------

Not accurate to call Ra an auction game. Instead, it's a push-your-luck game. Keep putting more items into the auction lot, or call the auction now and try to be the only one who's willing to pay? Do you dare to call the auction now on something you don't particularly like, on the chance that your opponent just can't resist it? Get what you want early and sit out, or try to play the whims of Ra till the end and risk having unspent money?

Triumphant design. If only the theme were better. Even Razzia had a better theme.

RATING: 7.5
Ra -- While this could have been just another bidding game, it it instead feels archetypal for its class: bidding for sets which differ not only in value but in function.

In Puerto Rico, the rules lack the elegance I require to place it in my top tier. In Ra, the rules [i]in general[/i] are elegant, but each time I play, I find myself having to re-learn the requirements for each of the sets. I see this as a lack of elegance in that regard. Yes, frequent play would alleviate this issue, but I find that for some non-abstract games, I never require a refresher, no matter how infrequently I play. It is only this minor inelegance that keeps Ra from my top tier.

Player mats available on BoardGameGeek.com have made the rules-refresher much faster and easier.

RATING: 3
Initial rating = 4

I actually didn't find the game as themeless as it's often claimed, theme has no connection to gameplay though. I can pinpoint my main problem with this game that it shares with many euros: arbitrary spread sheet scoring system. Throw on your martix some some linear and some square equations and make it so that you score some things during the game, but some things in the end. Whaa?

----------------------------------------------
Improved rating = 7

Not sure, maybe after half year of boring noninteractive euros has gotten to me and somehow I now think this is good. Current hypothesis after borrowing the game, soloing it and a play with 3 players is that I was taught the game wrongly and had wrong expectations. 

[i]This is not primarily an auction game, no matter what people say. This is primarily a tableau building game similar to 7 wonders[/i] (set collecting, VPs based on some arbitary matrix, theme of ancient civilisation and 3 ages each (hmmmmm....)) with auctions instead of drafting. 

What this means in comparison to 7 wonders is: Ra has simpler synergy between pieces (set collecting) but is far far more interactive, hence I'll rate both games the same for now. They both lack in connecting gameplay to theme though. Bizarrely, thinking of it Fairy Tale is much more "Ra with drafting" than 7 wonders, but designers messed up the theme - what dragons and whatnot, you must build ancient stuff!

Actually Ra desperately needs a big graphic overhaul (like Pegasus did with Modern Art) - if this could look a bit more like 7 wonders or at least Stone Age (and it could), the game would get much more popularity. 

----------------------------------------------
rating drips to 5.5 together with priest of ra. Falls 0.5 more. Sorry Ra, until you get the graphic redesign I like Priests of Ra better (looks nicer, has 2 sided tiles). Yeah yeah, Ra has marginally better tension and narrative, BUT 15 years old graphics! 

There's just nothing really gripping about this pair of games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Give the constrained choices on each turn, it's a wonder that Ra works at all -- and incredible that it's fantastic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
To me, Ra is a gem among the middle-weight Knizia pure auction games. A combination of push-your-luck and once-round auctions, its gameplay is distilled into making one of two choices during your turn – either draw a tile or call for an auction. 

What is distinct about Ra is the method of evaluation of a particular set of tiles, which takes into account several subtle elements such as how many Ra tiles have already been drawn and the value of the Sun in the middle. An upside is that there is no need to fine-tune the value of your bid as each player starts out with three fixed bidding values. Players can try calculating whether a particular set if worth a certain value, but in the end a gut instinct tends to work just as well. The ability to call for an auction is also unique to Ra, and is dependent on how well players evaluate the current set of tiles and the state of the other players. 

Granted, Ra is not without its flaws – it is terribly unintuitive at first blush, its complex and abstract scoring system can permanently put some players off and outliers in luck can skew the game in one person's favour. Regardless of its drawbacks, Ra is a brilliant design which expertly melds skill and luck in equal parts.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2015: 8. Comments based on several games against the AI in the iOS version.  I investigated Knizia's auction trilogy (at least Ra and Medici) via iOS rather than trying to hunt down old copies of the game. I quite like both, despite the fact that both apps are in need of an update.

With Ra, in particular I really like the sun token system, where other players have a chance to acquire your bid chips.  It keeps things civil, transparent and while still being an auction game and having that "stare down" element.  The brinkmanship involved in trying to get the best tiles before running out of auctions in the round is nice although it's not fun when Ra tiles show up with nothing else in the cue.  It's this element that, to me, makes Ra feel a little more random than Medici.  Theme is completely non-existent, but I hardly care.

Of the two, I *think* I prefer Medici, but I need to play both games against humans to have that "matching of wits" feeling to know for sure.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Knizia's best and one of the finest, most elegant designs in history. Everything works together beautifully and the progress of the game is sublime, with values shifting as time moves on. I love the integration of the bidding tokens into the lots - everything works together! A sheer pleasure to play - one I am always willing to play again. Perfect.

Check out "RA: In depth", an episode of my podcast Boardgame Babylon that is devoted to a discussion of RA. www.boardgamebabylon.com

Überplay Edition

RATING: 8

RATING: 6.5

*****

After several more plays, I have to say this is the worst Knizia game I've played.  There is a huge amount of luck involved in what tiles are drawn and when, particularly the Ra tiles.  Also, other players can play kingmaker rather inadvertently by calling Ra at times when it is not to their benefit but hurts one player and helps another.  Find something else if you're looking for a skill game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What is truly remarkable about my relationship with this game is that, in every single instance, I have come in last place with the least amount of fame points - and yet I love the game. (Update: no longer true! Yay!) This could be more revealing about me than Ra. Perhaps I just don't care about winning when assessing a game. Or perhaps, at the far end of the spectrum, I am so obsessed with winning that consistent loss presents me with an intriguing challenge. Regardless, Ra is a winner - and not just because he's the god of the sun. Despite rules that are a bit more lengthy and verbose than necessary (I am starting to think that this is a frequent artifact of translation from German), Ra is very easy to learn and teach. Play is fairly intuitive. My recommendation is to explain how scoring works first, as your choices in the game are all predicated upon the value of the tiles.

In Ra, players take turns drawing tiles from a bag, which go onto an auction track. These tiles represent monuments, aspects of civilization, pharaohs, gods, and so on, and are valued in different ways during the three scoring phases. Ra tiles (or a player may simply invoke Ra) go onto the auction/Ra track to create an auction phase, in which each player has the opportunity to make one bid (only!) for all the tiles accumulated upon the auction track. Winner takes all. Players bid with using a limited pool of sun tiles, and a scoring phase is initiated when no players have any sun tiles left to bid with - or the Ra track is filled up with Ra (auction) tiles. At the end of the third scoring phase, the game is over. Fame points received are kept hidden.

The chance element of drawing tiles from the bag, combined with the hidden scoring and the psychology of the short but sweet auctions helps prevent analysis-paralysis. This means that the pace of the game never bogs down and games are quick. It's quite reasonable to get multiple games in during an evening. I also really enjoy the tile collecting aspect of the game, trying to acquire different kinds of sets. Despite my failing to grasp a winning strategy, I have fun playing this game, and so does everyone else I've played it with. Something Ra does very well is keep downtime to a minimum and keep players engaged.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Well, I'm glad my instincts were right in saying during my first play of Ra, "This reminds me of that auction game, the one with the gangsters..." and somebody said, "Razzia!" and I said, "Yeah! I didn't like that one either."

After looking at players comments of Razzia!, I noticed that the first 5 comments, all high of course since they start in the 10's, all mentioned "Ra" in some way, shape or form and likened Razzia! to Ra. Hmmm...? Which came first? Ra or Razzia!? 'Cuz whoever designed the 2nd game definitely stole most of their ideas from the 1st one. I mean, for crying out loud, they played like EXACTLY THE SAME GAME!

To me the games are boring. Pull tiles(cards), call Ra(Razzia!), bid on tiles(cards), pull cards(tiles), call Razzia!(Ra), bid on cards(tiles). Which game are we playing anyway?

I hate the random epoch ending contrivance of pulling the red tiles. How about this? Keep some red tiles set aside and when somebody calls Ra!, put one of the red tiles on the red tile track. That would at least speed up the process of getting to the end of this boring game.

RATING: 4
This game was all about the rate of diminishing return.  When I first tried it I was so enamored with the system that I wanted to immediately go back to it to try to grog out how the whole thing worked.  Over time though I found that the game was made on lucky breaks.  You can try to stem the tide, but often you are going to get what you get.  Yes you can push your luck too far and create more valuable lots for others, and yes knowing when to time your bids is very important, but nothing is as important as getting the big run at the end of the round.

It's a kooky probability puzzle, that just ends up seeming more and more random the more I play it.

That said screaming "Ra! Ra! Ra!" is still fun (which is why this gets a 4).  I'd like this game more if you just screamed "Ra!" at people.

RATING: 9
What a surprise! It looks very dry like most old euros do but don't let the pasted on theme and dry artwork fool you. Ra is a very cool game that plays fast, is great with 3-4 players and where every decision feels important.

The best thing about Ra is the interaction between players. Most euros rely on blocking, taking other peoples stuff og cutting them off from gaining victory points. basically all interaction is happening on the board. Because it's auction game, the interaction in Ra is much more social. What's happening on the board is just a facilitator for a very rich, dynamic and intense player interaction.

Also, it's more tactical than strategic, which I'm a big fan of when playing euros.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ra is a set collection game.  You obtain sets of items that are scored by how many you obtain (such as the gold or Gods tiles), whether you have the most or the least (the Pharaoh tiles), or by whether you have different types or multiples of the same one (Civilization or Monument tiles).  The tiles are obtained in an auction.  On their turn, each player has the option of drawing a tile from the bag and adding it to the auction lot, or declaring an auction on the existing lot (invoking Ra).  The bag is seeded with an abundance of special Sun tiles.  These force an immediate auction, and they also act as the timer for the round (when x Sun tiles are revealed, the round is over).  Players have 4 bidding chits of varying value to bid with each round.  Auctions are once around, ending with the active player.

The trickiest thing is knowing when to invoke Ra.  Often, this is done to get others to bid and use up their bidding chits for that round, leaving you in an advantageous bidding position. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
Definitely a good one.  It has a nice auction element, and there are plenty of different kinds of tiles that are possible to get, making it entertaining to plan which ones you need.  My favorite unique feature of this game is that you are penalized if you don't collect certain tiles - I once finished with fewer points than I started the game with!  There is a fair amount of luck in this game, but it makes for variety, and if you play the percentages, you generally will end up OK.

UPDATE: I have to move this up to a 9, because it really is just so much fun.  I love the auctions and the unpredictability of the tiles - you just never know exactly how this one is going to go, yet it's light enough that it's always fun to play.

RATING: 9
Ra is a wonderfully tense asynchronous auction game.  you need to simultaneously pay attention to what other players need and what they might be worth to them, as well as what you yourself might need.  there is some much your luck - you can only win 3 sets of tiles, and perhaps not even that many if you wait too long. 

the scoring takes a little work to learn, but once you have that figured out - it's a great game that's easy to set up and play.  love.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Ra is a clever auction mechanic married to idiosyncratic scoring rules, essentially a VP spreadsheet. Its genius is in its simplicity. You make one choice on your turn, to push your luck or call an auction, and you do it again and again. That simple choice creates agonizing decisions--and it creates opportunities for players to force their opponents to make them. Sure, there's no real theme, and there's not a lot of variation in the gameplay, but when there's as much depth to the interaction as there is here, who cares?

Unlike many games, this one scales. With three players, it's probably the best game I know. Decisions are frequent, important, and the game is exactly as long as it should be. It's also great with four--and worth playing even with five. Tigris & Euphrates may be my favourite Knizia, but Ra is awfully close. Every time I play, I'm never, for even a moment, remotely bored.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Picked it up for cheap in a Tangathon, and I'm glad I did - Ra is an incredible game. Modern Art may have more interesting auctions, but Ra's set-collection mechanic sets it apart.

Gateway rating: 8 (would be a 9, but the scoring is slightly funky for newcomers)

RATING: 7
Ra is a well-designed auction game.  I always enjoy sessions of this game.  Although Goa is my favorite auction game, Ra hits the table when game length is an issue.

This is a great game to use for introducing new board gamers to auction games.  Like other Knizia games, it's simple enough that children who understand ordering and sets can play, and it's nuanced enough that adults of the same skill can challenge one another.

This is the best board game application for the iPhone.

RATING: 6
Okay, I KIND of see what all the hype was about.  This is quite a brilliant and unique (at least as far as my gaming experience goes) little game.  It has the pasted-on theme which is so typical of a lot of Euro-style games, but ancient Egypt seems as good a theme any, so why not?  A lot of little elements and mechanics, such as auction, bluffing, "push your luck", and set collecting, are seamlessly blended together to create a tense and competitive gaming experience.  The problem is, the first-time player has rather a lot of things to try and remember, and repeat plays don't seem to increase the fun all that much.  Game design: 4/5  Personal enjoyment: 2/5  Total: 6/10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
I'm having trouble articulating just what I hate about Ra, but it has something to do with the bizarre Frankenstein's Monster scoring with five points for this, negative two for that and a non-linear function f(x) for the number of partridges in the pear tree -- I had the same reaction to A Fistful of Penguins. I suspect that I am willing to put up with this kind of nonsense only when it is married to an interesting spatial element.

In Ra, the only interesting element is the auction, where players are each fixed to a maximum of 3 bids at predetermined values. The winning bid-tile is exchanged with the winning bid-tile from the last auction, so winning an auction can increase or decrease bidding power in later epochs.

The inelegant scoring has grown on me a little with experience, but it's still game I tolerate more than like. Repeated plays have convinced me that, assuming basic competence, the elements having most impact on the outcome are memory (unless discards are public or the number of each tile remaining is otherwise public; in some respects I prefer the iOS implementation because it does this for you) and whether or not the random tile draws favour your guesses or not. There are degrees of education in those guesses, of course, but guesses they remain.

Which is to say, while I enjoy auction games, Ra is really a [i]betting[/i] game -- you gamble that cashing out now will be worth more or less than cashing out later. You can make better bets than others by understanding the probabilities, and hedge your bets by pursuing a balanced strategy. But the impact of luck is still an irritant.

Ratings history: 4.5 -> 6 -> 6.5 -> 6 -> 4.5
