RATING: 10
Ra!

Ra is one of the first games played in my return to gaming (and introduction to eurogaming).  That was 10 years ago.  We are still playing Ra to this day (and will play 10 years from now).

Of course, it took us 5 years to get the rules correct (we kept putting back the Ra tiles into the mix after every round instead of taking them out of the game!).  After playing with right rules, our scores really took off (the game plays ever better with the right rules)!!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The balance between known and unknown information is near perfect, and the zero-sum bidding creates my favorite auction dynamic.  Some complain of the randomness, but creating strategies based on the probablities of gaining what you want to score highest and still have buying power for the next epoch is extremely satisfying.  
It reminds me of Tournament Style No-Limit Texas Holdem, in that luck CAN win out for the new/bad player, keeping them coming back, but the better player will certainly win more often.  Also, it is never the same game twice, as one's strategy must be shifted by the random tile draw.  Out of all the relatively light/accessible games I have played, this one is the most fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[Uberplay 2005 Edition] {Egypt; auction, set-collection} Ra is a very good and challenging auction game. It is one of my favorite Knizia's auction games (in line with High Society and Traumfabrik). The special scoring rule is the cornerstone of Ra. Its auction system is also unique: the used 'Sun' is bid together in next auction. Ra incorporates both tactical and strategic plays. Tactically, players collect as many tiles as they can in each Epoch. Strategically, players shall determine the ways to collect monuments and Sun toward the end of the game. Although players need only make 2 decisions each turn: draw or call "Ra" (using of "God" is usually trivial, esp. in late game), Ra is quite brain-teasing. 

Players have to carefully optimize their expected gain. This is a bit tricky because the calculation is non-linear: each kind of tile is equally important and is most useful during different stages of the game. Thus, the optimization work is not easy and involves assiduous estimation of risk. 

The Egyptian theme of Ra is very thin. In essence, it's a calculation game using bidding as the core mechanics. Nevertheless, the theme really helps in enhancing the feeling and color of Ra. Though it's a heavy calculation game, it has loads of fun and player interaction.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After a dozen or so games I've now raised my rating to a 10. Elegant gameplay with many tough decisions. This is the perfect auction game.

Update: I've dropped my rating. Not quite as fun as it used to be. Might just be burnout, but for now it's an 8.

Last played : Sept 2010

RATING: 7
I like the auction games that move relatively quickly.  Ra is one of the best ones of these, with its once-around bidding system and discrete bid increments.

The randomness of the draw makes the game a bit more luck-dependent than Modern Art (for example), but I like that in an auction game.  Otherwise the bidding process can deteriorate into IRR calculations and card-counting, which feels a lot like my job.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is an auction set collecting game with a twist.  Each player starts with 3 numbered tiles.  When you bid on an auction, your bid is one of the numbered tiles.  The highest numbered tile wins the auction.  When you win, you lose the tile you bid and gain the tile that won the last bid for use later in the game.

It would be a ten if I really loved the game; I admire the mechanics but I'm not in love with the game. still excellent. 

originally 7, june '14. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The words "I call Ra," will be the most terrifying words you will ever hear.  This is a very fun bidding game where you never know what item is around the corner, and you could strike it rich or lose everything.  This is a game where you push your luck and hope that you hold out better than the next guy.  You hope the other player next to you doesn't draw that last pharoh card, you're hoping you can grab a nile card to water your fields, you're hoping the other guy doesn't use his god card to snatch that one card you need off the table.  Anything goes in this game, there is tense hear break and eyebrows will furrow when intense decisions have to be made.  So will you push your luck, or surrender yoru soul to the almighty RA?  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

Now it's just released "Razzia!", an identical card game but with Mafia background and a lot cheaper, but this one seems to be special (Alea bookcase, components, background theme).

RATING: 7
Just played one round tonight w/roomies.  I thought it would be deeper than it seemed to be.  Maybe it is and we just didn't give it much time to play deep (due to time constraints when playing).  I think as we play more we'll find more depth to it.  Certainly had a very nice FLOW to it.  Didn't really feel bored or that there was too much AP in it, so that's nice.

EDIT: 5 player takes forever.  I don't like too many players with it (too much AP and waiting for your turn), and I also dislike having to pass the little black bag back and forth - I'm thinking a set of bags - one for each player - would be so much easier - or proxy one player to do the drawing and placing.  Something where you don't have to pass the bag between 5 players over a somewhat large table (the table size may be a contributor to this situation).  

I'm not *feeling* it.  With fewer players it's not bad, but it still doesn't *grab* me the way some games do.  It's not horrible w/2 or 3 players, but not great.  5 players, I dislike very much. So that's why it's a low rating for me.

---------------------------------
18-JUL-2009 - Played for first time as a 3-player game. Really love the auction mechanism for this game...there is a lot to evaluate with each auction and even each turn -- deciding whether to call an auction is something to consider each turn. I also found that when you have low bid amounts you still have some power if you use them in the right way.

I think 2-player might be a bit lacking. 3 is good. I suspect 4 will be best and 5 might be a little bit too many, but am looking forward to trying both 4 and 5 out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A fine auction game that places limits on the amounts you can bid. I enjoy the fact that bidding is not just an exercise in valuation, but also in positioning. How much is the current lot worth to you, and to the others? But also, how much is it worth to use your current bidding token and trade it in for the one in the middle of the table? These are interesting questions. That said, the set collection aspect of play is merely ok. I will play again, but I wish the game surrounding the auction was more dynamic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ra is a game that I haven't figured out how to play well yet, but at the same time I can tell there is a lot of depth there.  I enjoy all of the interlaced scoring opportunities, especially how the winning bidding chip becomes part of the next lot, and the tough choice between paying too much for a questionable lot weighed against letting another player have it for too little.  Definitely print out and laminate the player aid here on the Geek, it lowers the scoring chaos by an order of magnitude.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Pure Auction Game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's tempting to write it off as just an auction game, but there's much more going on. Your quantity of "money" is a surprisingly minor factor. Ra is all about timing and properly judging the state of the game; the needs of your opponents, the probabilities, the value of tiles to you and to others, the impending end of the round... anyway, it's fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
An interesting and unique concept.  I found that it didn't end up mattering which tiles I got and that all of the tiles were basically the same value.  At that point, the decisions became simple and it was just about getting as many tiles as possible.  I'd play it again, but for some reason I don't get excited about playing it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.3
The bidding system in this is fun, unique and tense. There is real strategy here, knowing when and what to bid. The Ra tiles are a little too numerous and annoying however; I feel the game would benefit from more negative scorers and less random Ra tiles, making for bigger more complicated betting situations with more tension. The set collection is fun and the tension as I sit and wait for that last building tile while holding on to a big betting chip - so much depth here in such a little game.

RATING: 10

Also I love how a push your luck element is incorporated into the game. And it seems so simple and organic - really elegant. *

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Great play balance, with many paths to victory. Quick and compelling. Plays very well with three, four or five players. I once thought Ra was best with five, but now think it shines most with three players, as having four sun/bidding tiles in a three-player game definitely gives players a bit more control and is a bit more forgiving regardless of how quickly a round ends or how long one lasts. Folks who complain Ra is all luck do not understand the extent of control the simple decision of drawing or starting an auction gives each player on each turn. On my all-time best list.

RATING: 9.5
This is the first Reiner game that I ever played. Very interesting game where it is very difficult to value some of the "lots." Of all the auction games I have played, this is the one that is the most difficult for me and I just don't play it very well. I think the game rewards balanced play (try to get good -- not necessarily great -- returns on your suns while getting another good -- not necessarily great, but not bad -- sun tile in return. There is a bit of a learning curve for newbies, but everybody ends up having fun with this one. Ra! Ra! Ra! Played with 3 to 5 players and all were enjoyable.

Update: I have been getting much better at this game and I now have a winning streak of 4 games. I still love this game, even when I lose. The best of the auction games.

RATING: 8
Probably my favourite auction game. The scoring mechanics mean that auctions will normally be worth a little more to some players than others. The ticking Ra clock and the push your luck mechanism provides some real tension to decisions and means that players with smaller valued bidding tiles can often do better than those with larger ones as long as the power of calling Ra is used well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Despite the seeming simplicity of this game it has been a bit of a minor hit with my group and it has gotten requested far more than I ever would have expected.

The play count, ease of explanation and play time are obviously in it's favor but the game itself is an elegantly designed auction and valuation game with a good push your luck element to it.

There is no wasted space in the design and it really is what I would consider a classic euro.  Sometimes it is refreshing to play something like this worth such a crisp and light rule set, such a limited amount of symbology that by turn 2 everyone is fully grasping the game.

There are some player mats on BGG that are absolutely indispensable in my opinion.  They make the game vastly easier to explain, to track and to score.  Print them and use them!

RATING: 9
A near-perfect auction game.  Can be a bit intimidating at first with the number of different things that come up for auction, and like all auction games it takes a few plays to really get the hang of it.  But the payoff for learning is huge.  In particular, the mechanic of having the currency for the next round (suns) be part of the auction gives this game that extra dimension that makes it a joy to play every time.  Also one of the few games that I find to be equally good across its entier range of number of players.

3 players: 9
4 players: 9
5 players: 9

RATING: 10
Text book Knizia.  The more I play the more I enjoy it.  The fun to time ratio is only beat by other Knizia's.  Bliss.  The trick for me is to get other people to overpay for their tiles.  The varying values of tiles to each player after the first round, makes for interesting and very real decisions.  As with all auction games, weird plays by opponenets can shift this game... but it feels different in this auction, its more changes the ebb and flow instead of kingmaking.  The better the players the better the game.

I love the extreme valuation changes in tiles by the third epoch.  Trying to avoid bidding wars by ensuring other peoples coveted tiles are not included in tiles you covet is fun.  This game has a je ne sais quoi which takes from a game I like to a raucous amazing time.  It strikes the perfect balance between social and strategic.

RATING: 9
This is undoubtedly my favorite auction game.  I loved playing this online at BSW, and love playing it in person with my Uberplay reprint even more.  This is one of those games that definitely gets better with repeated plays because you gain a better understanding of the scoring system, and how much different sets of tiles are worth at different points in the game.  The open sun bidding chips are unlike any other auction system I've played before, and really make this game special.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ra is an auction game with some unusual scoring mechanisms.  It's played over three ages and you have three bidding tiles which you can use in an age.  When you use a tile you exchange it for the one in the current auction but flip the new one over until the following age.  So you can never win more than three auctions in an age.  If you use a high numbered tile (13 is the highest) to guarantee a win of a juicy pot, you may be trading your future away if the new bidding tile you get is a low number.  Similarly you may bid on a weak pot just to trade up your 1 tile.

Ra sun tiles periodically come out, prompting an auction, and eventually triggering the end of an age.  Wait too long to win an auction and the age could end and you get nothing.  If you declare an auction you get last bid, which can be a neat trick to force someone to use up a high bidding tile or let you win the auction cheap.  But if you start an auction and no one bids you have to.

The game is interesting and fun, but luck can play a factor if the right tiles come out at the right time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Ra may very well be the quintessential auction game. Auction in one of its purest form.

You can see this when you consider the two basic actions in the game: draw a new tile or calling Ra (starting an auction). And this is it. Draw and auction.

There is an action allowed by owning a God tile, but this is a special action.

So all the game revolve around those two actions and there is so, so much to think. Which of the suns still remain, which tiles are in the board and which are in the bag, which sun you will get if you win the auction, and so forth.

An amazing auction game, for sure.

My review (in portuguese) is [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/782793/ra-resenha-em-portugues-review-in-portuguese]here[/url].

Edit: After some hundreds games online, I boost the rating by 1.0 - Ra sure earn it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very good game. I might expect that I wouldn't like it as there is a lot of randomness (at least technically) and player interaction is somewhat indirect. But it's an auction game with constrained bidding (which is of great interest) that plays smoothly and in a short time.

There's also a strong push-your-luck element that I hadn't really expected. It's good and not disruptive but I wouldn't say it's the reason for the game being good.

I have high desire to play and replay Ra, which is really unusual for me. To reflect this I'm giving it a high rating.

...What is great about this game is the small number of decisions and options combined with the feeling of great differences resulting from what choices you make. The questions asked of you are sharp. It doesn't waste your time.

RATING: 8
Somewhat dry, but enjoyable nonetheless.  The game flies by because of the limited number of actions available to you, but still presents you with a good deal of decision-making. I like my games to have theme, and my first game of Ra a couple years ago was my first exposure to the concept of a pasted-on theme.  After the first epoch, I said to myself "this has nothing to with ancient Egypt? how strange."  Like I said though, the simple auctions and lightning fast gameplay, as well as its ability to scale for a large number of players make this game well worthwhile.  Also, the first game I logged in my quest to start logging plays.

The game works great with 2, and I can't imagine why it's not advertised as such.  There a number of tile distributions floating around here, including one from Knizia's re-implementation of this game, Razzia, which does advertise as 2 players

RATING: 7
07/2008:8.5
Hahaha!!! I finally have Alea's version of RA!!

Since I am a Knizia fan, this comes as no surprise. Just one play and I already know I like it. There is something about the tension and the decision making that makes this game shine. Every single variable is interwoven. A gain here is negated by a corresponding loss in a different area. Excellent!

On subsequent plays, the game retains its uniqueness and complexity. This game is just so hard to grasp and to master. A small change is enough to swing the game one way or another. Hallmark of a great game.

091010 Retains its place on the top of my collection. Just plain delicious. Knizia's games are just all elegant.

RATING: 8
I wasn't entirely sure what to expect with this game, unlike most, I enjoy bidding in games... but a game based around bidding doesn't necessarily excite me.  I watched a few videos and the game seemed really simple with complicated scoring (something I usually loathe).  When you play it though, man this game is just fast paced and entertaining through and through.  Because of the different scoring methods and the Ra tile mechanic, there's tons of room for mind games, forced auctions and push-your-luck.  The way the Sun biding tiles work is brilliant as it cuts out a lot of the stress of min-maxing bids, you only have a small set of values and you have to figure out how best to use them.

Really a ton of fun!

RATING: 8
RA is an indispensable auction game. It has a lot to think about with the different types of tiles and scoring conditions, but like Puerto Rico, individual moments of choice boil down to just a couple options (in this case: force an auction or draw a tile, or use a god tile if you have one), so the game stays fast paced and accessible despite there being many things to consider. The press your luck element in this game is ever present and very engaging. One of my go-to games for introducing non-gamers into the hobby.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Knizia; Ra is an auction game with an Ancient Egyptian theme. Each turn players are able to purchase three lots of tiles with their bidding tiles. Once a player has purchased his three lots for the round, the other players continue until they do likewise, which may set up a situation with a single uncontested player bidding on tiles before the end of the round occurs. Tension builds because the round may end before all players have had a chance to win their three lots for the epoch. The tiles give either immediate points, prevent negative points for not having certain types at the end of the round (epoch), or give points after the final round. The game lasts for three epochs. The game offers a short learning curve, and experienced players find it both fast-moving and a quick play. Re-implemented as: Razzia!,  Ra - The Dice Game 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A pure auction game, Ra is beautifully presented even though the theme is laughably tacked on. Unless at some point there were four competing pharaohs trying to outbid each other for pyramids that I haven't heard about. I only spent a second thinking about all that though, because once the game was afoot, I was too engrossed to worry about it.

As usual in a Dr. Knizia game, the structure is fairly simple but a brilliant twist turns it into a real brain burner. In this case, players are given a set of three or four tiles with a fairly wide spread of values. When an auction happens, you can only bid the exact value of a tile you hold. When you win, you leave your winning bid tile in the center of the board and it becomes part of the next auction lot. As such, players must constantly evaluate not only the auction lots, but whether or not they are worth swapping one of your high numbered bids for a low one, as a consequence of the deal. To add to the dilemma, the total value of the bid tiles you end the game with are summed and compared, with points handed out to the leader and worse, taken away from the person with the lowest total. You have to be careful not to run yourself out of buying power at the wrong time, or you can end up losing a whole lot of points.

There is also a tense push-your-luck aspect to how the auction lots are set up, which I won't detail here. Just know that it also adds a lot of decision space and drama to the proceedings.

This is a legendary game among longtime Eurogamers and I absolutely see why. It is every bit as good as the best Knizia titles I've played and certainly worth tracking down for anyone that enjoys auction games as a genre.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Excellent push-your-luck bidding game.  Scoring is a bit convoluted, especially to explain,  but isn't too bad once you get going.  Theme is a bit of a paste-up...Rivers and floods are okay (but really,  maybe it should have been arable land and rain),  but why does your civilization keep getting forgotten from round to round?  Why are your rulers duking it out?   What they heck are all these cosmic suns being tossed around???

More plays have shown this to be a very solid bidding game - elegant in the limited bid increments,  and cleverly disguised different scoring mechanics.   Although, of course,  the theme is completely nonsense other than having random art.  The civilization ability of rock volleyballs?!

RATING: 7.5
Ra is a nice take on an auction game with a few quirky mechanics. You only get one chance for a bid which makes your position in the bidding order important. Bidding is done with money tokens and you always collect the last token used for a bid for yourself. I slightly dislike how the money works in this game, but it also provides a few more variables to think about so I'll let it slide. The scoring mechanics felt a bit complicated at first and not very intuitive, a couple of plays are required to get an idea of what is worth what. The game is quite abstract which for me reduces the score somewhat. Plays fast and does not overstay its welcome.

RATING: 8.6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Man, this is a game that doesn’t look like much from the outside and is certainly over priced, but I had a really good time with my first game. I think the whole table came away surprised with how good it was. It’s a pretty simple game: on your turn you can draw a tile, invoke Ra (start an auction), or use a god tile to exchange another for another tile. If you ever draw a Ra tile, Ra is invoked. Auctions are quick because you can only win so many auctions on a turn and you know exactly what everyone can bid, so how much is this set of tiles worth to you? After drawing enough Ra tiles, the epoch ends, most of the tiles are scored, and the ones without a scarab are removed from your tableau. You play three epochs this way, do a final scoring, and count up your points.

I think my wife said it best: she was able to play, keep a handle on it, and do pretty well, even with our son distracting her. There’s lots of room for strategic play and the art is really nicely done.

Highly recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very fun, "one-bid-only" auction game with some noticeable similarity to Strozzi (but this came first). Interesting balance between getting the most you can with your sun tokens and trying to get the other players to use up theirs for less. 

Huge points can potentially be gained if you're the last bidder in an epoch, as no-one can outbid you, but you risk being caught out if the Ra tiles end the epoch sooner than you expect.

Upgraded to a 9 after 11 plays; I wasn't all that impressed with it at first, but it's really grown on me. Understanding how you need to carefully manage the sun tokens really makes the game, and the push-your-luck element keeps it from being predictable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Better than I expected. The scoring is a lot to take in so it took a game before I really knew what was going on. It plays quick and works pretty well as an auction/set collection game.

Sold before I played it. Owned within the group anyway.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
{ P - [3] 4 5 }

Fun: 1
Luck: 9
Strategy: 2

The box cover lied! Ra is inherently a crapshoot if everyone invokes reasonably intelligently. The flavor is perfect and there's something almost elegant about how the game functions entirely off one process (hence the gateway status) but unfortunately there's really no way of circumventing the game's dumbass pull-from-the-bag mechanic, destined to screw people over or give them the nuts at the drop of a hat. Experienced players can decide based on the number of reds pulled, X round SHOULD only last about Y turns longer, but you can't ever say for sure, meaning game-breaking uncertainty abounds. Players can bid with their last token because in all likelihood the epoch will end before a better pot accumulates and then watch as the straggler lucks into multiple pharaohs, civs, etc. Conversely someone can go all out during a round, capitalizing on lucksacky opportunities but picking up low suns in return, expecting to invoke more often in the following round, except when that time comes players pull nothing but reds and plagues and the round ends so quickly the low suns never get the opportunity to win any pot of significance, meaning they get negative points for civs and only get to trade up one of their suns, making what should have been a favorable payoff into a blind shaft. Moreover pretty much every game comes down to the dreaded "last place, first place" scenario where two players are left towards the end of the third epoch. One guy is in a weaker position and requires specific tiles to have a shot at winning while the other person is in a better shape so his needs are more general. Neither player invokes because for the first guy, the pot doesn't have what he needs. If he invokes, the other guy gives it to him and he loses. For the second guy, why invoke when the pot is only getting better and better? In other words, one player is forced to help the other because he can't win otherwise, all to the detriment of the third guy who invoked out. And the worst part? You can't do anything about it. Circumstances inevitably stack up like so and players getting screwed don't have an out. Let's not kid ourselves - basically everybody plays this game at some point; with any luck you'll tire of it sooner than I did.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Had played a prototype with Jay Tummelson at Game Storm 2008

7 after 1 play

Bidding mechanic, which includes bidding for the sun token, is innovative and creates many different values for each player to consider. However, there is a substantial push your luck element in the game and this may not appeal to many players, particularly those who prefer heavier games. Player interaction is reasonably high. Artwork is rather plain and game components quality average, but a newer recent version has included improvements to these.

I own and love Ra: The Dice game, but this is definitely meatier... great auction game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I know I'm in the minority, but I find the face-to-face game unfulfilling. The icons are cluttered and hard to distinguish from across the table. The scoring system is all over the map. The public knowledge bidding takes some getting used to, as you know going into some auctions that you can't win them. I finally feel like I can evaluate auction lots better after 15 plays. Heavy, heavy luck of the draw. Even when I've won, it never felt like it was because of my decision making -- the game made my decisions for me. Better than Razzia for the nice BGG player aid and the ultra-cool blue Ra turn marker with the gold ink... [UPDATE] Playing on BSW is far more engaging than playing F2F for me -- it's easier to see what other players have, and thus what may be more important for them in auction lots. Also cuts the fiddliness of tile drawing/scoring dramatically. On BSW, I'd rate Ra a solid 7.5... [UPDATE 2] I can't think of another game that fascinates me AND frustrates me as much as Ra. Especially when good decision making gets punishes -- such as holding on to bid tiles to try and get something of value, and having 6 of the next 7 tiles drawn be Ra tiles, so you end up with nothing for an entire Epoch -- that's not strategy, that's not skill, that's pure luck. Bad luck. [UPDATE 3] Finally enough plays (and actually requests) to bump this to an 8. It is a very good game, and I enjoy it with 3 and 4. The more I play, the more it makes sense -- and the more it makes sense, the more I can enjoy it. Still too cumbersome and slow for me with 5 players, tho.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Best auction game I'm aware of, unless you count Amun Re. Brilliant.

Update: It's good, very good. But I'm not. I'm bad, very bad at this game. BUT, it does say something that I still enjoy playing it :-)

RATING: 7

The scoring is a bit convoluted and I wouldn't have enjoyed the game as much without the player mats the owner had printed.  The random lots take some getting used too as well.  I think I had more fun play Colloseum, but Ra certainly felt more strategic.  I'd like to play again!

RATING: 9
Great quick, tactical, bidding game. Lots of tension when the Ra track gets close to finishing and you still want to grab a bunch of good tiles with your high suns. Theme is irrelevant, scoring convoluted as befits a Knizia game. 

Update: upgraded my rating, this game grows on me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like the bidding mechanism, as well as the multiple ways to score depending on the combination of tiles you've collected, and the penalty incurred from the lack of certain ones.  However, the randomness of the tile drawing does not necessarily reward people for playing well.  There is a press your luck element to Ra in which one has to decide whether to bid now or pass in hopes for better stuff before the current epoch ends.  The game is fun, and I will definitely need to play it more to get a better feel for it, but to the gamer in me my first impression is that Ra may be a tad too shallow.

RATING: 7.2
How can simply bidding on lots be so fun?  Simple, given the nice scoring reference on the gameboard:  Having the most of some things, or multiples of others, or certain combinations of some, or complete sets of still others gains you points, while having none, or the least of certain things, loses you points.  With each bid, you are not only helping to fate your points for the current epoch, but also determining your bid potential for the next epoch, in a cleverly implemented mechanism.  The

RATING: 8.5
We bought this from Tanga for our Christmas present (2006).  It doesn't get as many plays as I would like since it is usually just the wife and I.

I often find myself pulling my hair out during this game when faced with decisions.  It provides a nice tension because of the random tile draw.

Edit:  We actually have played this more now that my wife has gotten the hang of it.  I used to clobber her, now it is the other way around.

RATING: 10
After 20+ Plays: My favorite auction game, and one of my favorite games overall.  The mechanics are exceedingly simple, but there are lots of interesting decisions (not to mention plain ol' fun) arising out of them.

After 50+ Plays: This just doesn't get old for me.  I'd play it a lot more if people were willing, and would probably be happy to play at least once every week.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Despite not fully understanding the basic strategy for this game until turn 2, I really enjoyed my first play. The balance between getting the tiles you want, forcing others to bid before they're ready, and setting up good bidding tiles for the next round is excellent.

Definitely looking forward to playing this again.

RATING: 10
2-16-08:  It was hard for me to ultimately give this game a 10 because it is so dissimilar from the other games I highly covet.  Nevertheless, this game epitomizes fun in my opinion, and I can't ever foresee my love for it, or my desire to pull it off the shelf, ever dissipating.  One note:  I have seen numerous individuals have trouble with this game after the first few plays, only to see their appreciation grow after they'd gotten the hang of it (myself included).  If you don't see what all of the hullabaloo is about, I recommend you ask yourself if you've given it more than 3 tries.

06/30/06:  Rating 9:  If you play Ra and don't pee your pants in excitement, you're not human.
